dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Window, very small in the distance, illuminated. All around this is an almost totally black screen.  Now, the camera moves slowly towards the window which is almos postage stamp in the frame, other forms appear; barbed wi cyclone fencing, and now, looming up against an early mor sky, enormous iron grille work.  Camera travels up what i shown to be a gateway of gigantic proportions and holds o top of it - a huge initial "K" showing darker and darker the dawn sky.  Through this and beyond we see the fairy-t mountaintop of Xanadu, the great castle a sillhouette as summit, the little window a distant accent in the darknes

dialogues.speaker: TELLING SOMETHING OF
dialogues.text: The literally incredible domain of CHARLES FOSTER KANE. Its right flank resting for nearly forty miles on the Gul Coast, it truly extends in all directions farther than th can see.  Designed by nature to be almost completely bare flat - it was, as will develop, practically all marshland Kane acquired and changed its face - it is now pleasantly uneven, with its fair share of rolling hills and one very sized mountain, all man-made.  Almost all the land is imp either through cultivation for farming purposes of throug careful landscaping, in the shape of parks and lakes.  Th castle dominates itself, an enormous pile, compounded of genuine castles, of European origin, of varying architect dominates the scene, from the very peak of the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: GOLF LINKS, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: Past which we move.  The greens are straggly and overgrow the fairways wild with tropical weeds, the links unused a not seriously tended for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT WAS ONCE A GOOD-SIZED ZOO, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: Of the Hagenbeck type.  All that now remains, with one  exception, are the individual plots, surrounded by moats, which the animals are kept, free and yet safe from each o and the landscape at large.  (Signs on several of the plo indicate that here there were once tigers, lions, girrafe

dialogues.speaker: THE MONKEY TERRACE, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: In the foreground, a great obscene ape is outlined agains dawn murk.  He is scratching himself slowly, thoughtfully looking out across the estates of Charles Foster Kane, to distant light glowing in the castle on the hill.

dialogues.speaker: THE ALLIGATOR PIT, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: The idiot pile of sleepy dragons.  Reflected in the muddy the lighted window.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAGOON, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: The boat landing sags.  An old newspaper floats on the su of the water - a copy of the New York Enquirer."  As it m across the frame, it discloses again the reflection of th window in the castle, closer than before.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT SWIMMING POOL, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: It is empty.  A newspaper blows across the cracked floor the tank.

dialogues.speaker: THE COTTAGES, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: In the shadows, literally the shadows, of the castle.  As move by, we see that their doors and windows are boarded and locked, with heavy bars as further protection and sea

dialogues.speaker: A DRAWBRIDGE, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: Over a wide moat, now stagnant and choked with weeds.  We across it and through a huge solid gateway into a formal perhaps thirty yards wide and one hundred yards deep, whi extends right up to the very wall of the castle.  The  landscaping surrounding it has been sloppy and causal for long time, but this particular garden has been kept up in perfect shape.  As the camera makes its way through it, t the lighted window of the castle, there are revealed rare exotic blooms of all kinds.  The dominating note is one o almost exaggerated tropical lushness, hanging limp and  despairing.  Moss, moss, moss.  Ankor Wat, the night the King died.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW, (MINIATURE)
dialogues.text: Camera moves in until the frame of the window fills the f of the screen.  Suddenly, the light within goes out.  Thi stops the action of the camera and cuts the music which h been accompanying the sequence.  In the glass panes of th window, we see reflected the ripe, dreary landscape of Mr Kane's estate behind and the dawn sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very long shot of Kane's enormous bed, silhouetted agai the enormous window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An incredible one.  Big, impossible flakes of snow, a too picturesque farmhouse and a snow man.  The jingling of sl bells in the musical score now makes an ironic reference Indian Temple bells - the music freezes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosebud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pulls back, showing the whole scene to be cont in one of those glass balls which are sold in novelty sto all over the world.  A hand - Kane's hand, which has been holding the ball, relaxes.  The ball falls out of his han bounds down two carpeted steps leading to the bed, the ca following.  The ball falls off the last step onto the mar floor where it breaks, the fragments glittering in the fi rays of the morning sun.  This ray cuts an angular patter across the floor, suddenly crossed with a thousand bars o light as the blinds are pulled across the window. The foot of Kane's bed.  The camera very close.  Outlined against the shuttered window, we can see a form - the for a nurse, as she pulls the sheet up over his head.  The ca follows this action up the length of the bed and arrives the face after the sheet has covered it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the screen as the camera moves in are the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stirring, brassy music is heard on the soundtrack (which, course, sounds more like a soundtrack than ours.) The screen in the projection room fills our screen as the title appears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE:  Here follows a typical news digest short, one of t regular monthly or bi-monthly features, based on public e or personalities.  These are distinguished from ordinary  newsreels and short subjects in that they have a fully de editorial or storyline.  Some of the more obvious  characteristics of the "March of Time," for example, as w as other documentary shorts, will be combined to give an  authentic impression of this now familiar type of short s As is the accepted procedure in these short subjects, a n is used as well as explanatory titles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legendary was the Xanadu where  Kubla Kahn decreed his stately  pleasure dome - (with quotes in his  voice) "Where twice five miles of fertile  ground, with walls and towers were  girdled 'round."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, almost as legendary is  Florida's XANADU - world's largest  private pleasure ground.  Here, on  the deserts of the Gulf Coast, a  private mountain was commissioned,  successfully built for its landlord.   Here in a private valley, as in  the Coleridge poem, "blossoms many  an incense-bearing tree."  Verily,  "a miracle of rare device."

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES FOSTER KANE
dialogues.text: Opening shot of great desolate expanse of Florida coastli (1940 - DAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Series of shots showing various aspects of Xanadu, all as might be photographed by an ordinary newsreel cameraman - photographed, but not atmospheric to the extreme extent o Prologue (1940).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping the quotes) Here, for Xanadu's landlord, will  be held 1940's biggest, strangest  funeral; here this week is laid to  rest a potent figure of our Century -  America's Kubla Kahn - Charles  Foster Kane.  In journalism's  history, other names are honored  more than Charles Foster Kane's,  more justly revered.  Among  publishers, second only to James  Gordon Bennet the First: his  dashing, expatriate son; England's  Northcliffe and Beaverbrook;  Chicago's Patterson and McCormick;

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER TYCOON OF THIS OR ANY OTHER GENERATION.
dialogues.text: Shot of a huge, screen-filling picture of Kane.  Pull bac show that it is a picture on the front page of the "Enqui surrounded by the reversed rules of mourning, with masthe and headlines. (1940)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great number of headlines, set in different types and  different styles, obviously from different papers, all  announcing Kane's death, all appearing over photographs o Kane himself (perhaps a fifth of the headlines are in for languages).  An important item in connection with the hea is that many of them - positively not all - reveal passio conflicting opinions about Kane.  Thus, they contain vari the words "patriot," "democrat," "pacifist," "war-monger, "traitor," "idealist," "American," etc.

dialogues.speaker: YEARS HE WAS.
dialogues.text: Newsreel shots of San Francisco during and after the fire followed by shots of special trains with large streamers: Relief Organization."  Over these shots superimpose the d 1906. Artist's painting of Foch's railroad car and peace negoti if actual newsreel shot unavailable.  Over this shot  sumperimpose the date - 1918.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denver's Bonfils and Sommes; New  York's late, great Joseph Pulitzer;  America's emperor of the news  syndicate, another editorialist  and landlord, the still mighty and  once mightier Hearst.  Great names  all of them - but none of them so loved, hated, feared, so often  spoken - as Charles Foster Kane. The San Francisco earthquake.   First with the news were the Kane  papers.  First with Relief of the  Sufferers, First with the news of  their Relief of the Sufferers. Kane papers scoop the world on the  Armistice - publish, eight hours  before competitors, complete details  of the Armistice teams granted the  Germans by Marshall Foch from his  railroad car in the Forest of  Compeigne.  For forty years appeared  in Kane newsprint no public issue  on which Kane papers took no stand. No public man whom Kane himself  did not support or denounce - often  support, then denounce.  Its humble  beginnings, a dying dailey -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots with the date - 1898 (to be supplied) Shots with the date - 1910 (to be supplied) Shots with the date - 1922 (to be supplied) Headlines, cartoons, contemporary newreels or stills of t following:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN SUFFRAGE
dialogues.text: The celebrated newsreel shot of about 1914.

dialogues.speaker: PROHIBITION
dialogues.text: Breaking up of a speakeasy and such. 3.  T.V.A.

dialogues.speaker: LABOR RIOTS
dialogues.text: Brief clips of old newreel shots of William Jennings Brya Theodore Roosevelt, Stalin, Walter P. Thatcher, Al Smith, McKinley, Landon, Franklin D. Roosevelt and such.  Also, newsreels of the elderly Kane with such Nazis as Hitler a Goering; and England's Chamberlain and Churchill. Shot of a ramshackle building with old-fashioned presses through plate glass windows and the name "Enquirer" in ol fashioned gold letters. (1892)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane's empire, in its glory, held  dominion over thirty-seven  newpapers, thirteen magazines, a  radio network.  An empire upon an  empire.  The first of grocery  stores, paper mills, apartment  buildings, factories, forests, ocean-liners - An empire through  which for fifty years flowed, in  an unending stream, the wealth of  the earth's third richest gold  mine...  Famed in American legend  is the origin of the Kane fortune...   How, to boarding housekeeper Mary  Kane, by a defaulting boarder, in  1868 was left the supposedly  worthless deed to an abandoned  mine shaft: The Colorado Lode. The magnificent Enquirer Building  of today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1891-1911 - a map of the USA, covering the entire screen, in animated diagram shows the Kane publications spreading city to city.  Starting from New York, minature newboys s madly to Chicago, Detroit, St. Louis, Los Angeles, San  Francisco, Washington, Atlanta, El Paso, etc., screaming  "Wuxtry, Kane Papers, Wuxtry." Shot of a large mine going full blast, chimneys belching trains moving in and out, etc.  A large sign reads "Color Lode Mining Co." (1940)  Sign reading; "Little Salem, CO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old still shot of Little Salem as it was 70 years ago  (identified by copper-plate caption beneath the still). ( Shot of early tintype stills of Thomas Foster Kane and hi wife, Mary, on their wedding day.  A similar picture of M Kane some four or five years later with her little boy, C Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-seven years later, before a  Congressional Investigation, Walter  P.  Thatcher, grand old man of  Wall Street, for years chief target  of Kane papers' attack on "trusts,"  recalls a journey he made as a  youth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of Capitol, in Washington D.C. Shot of Congressional Investigating Committee (reproducti existing J.P. Morgan newsreel).  This runs silent under  narration.  Walter P. Thatcher is on the stand.  He is fl by his son, Walter P. Thatcher Jr., and other partners. being questioned by some Merry Andrew congressmen.  At th moment, a baby alligator has just been placed in his lap, causing considerable confusion and embarrassment. Newsreel close-up of Thatcher, the soundtrack of which no fades in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  because of that trivial  incident...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fact, however, is it not,  that in 1870, you did go to  Colorado?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In connection with the Kane affairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  My firm had been appointed  trustees by Mrs. Kane for the  fortune, which she had recently  acquired.  It was her wish that I  should take charge of this boy,  Charles Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same month in Union Square -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it not a fact that on that  occasion, the boy personally  attacked you after striking you in  the stomach with a sled?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud laughter and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, I will read to this  committee a prepared statement I  have brought with me - and I will  then refuse to answer any further  questions.  Mr.  Johnson, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young assistant hands him a sheet of paper from a brief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading it) "With full awareness of the meaning  of my words and the responsibility  of what I am about to say, it is  my considered belief that Mr.   Charles Foster Kane, in every  essence of his social beliefs and by the dangerous manner in which  he has persistently attacked the  American traditions of private  property, initiative and opportunity  for advancement, is - in fact -  nothing more or less than a  Communist."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newsreel of Union Square meeting, section of crowd carryi banners urging the boycott of Kane papers.  A speaker is the platform above the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fading in on  soundtrack) - till the words "Charles Foster  Kane" are a menace to every working  man in this land.  He is today  what he has always been and always  will be - A FASCIST!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet another opinion - Kane's  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent newsreel on a windy platform, flag-draped, in fron the magnificent Enquirer building.  On platform, in full  ceremonial dress, is Charles Foster Kane.  He orates sile

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES FOSTER KANE.
dialogues.text: Same locale, Kane shaking hands out of frame. Another newsreel shot, much later, very brief, showing Ka older and much fatter, very tired-looking, seated with hi second wife in a nightclub.  He looks lonely and unhappy the midst of the gaiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice married, twice divorced -  first to a president's niece, Emily  Norton - today, by her second  marriage, chatelaine of the oldest  of England's stately homes.  Sixteen  years after that - two weeks after his divorce from Emily Norton -  Kane married Susan Alexander,  singer, at the Town Hall in Trenton,  New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: FEW PRIVATE LIVES WERE MORE PUBLIC.
dialogues.text: Period still of Emily Norton (1900).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reconstructed silent newsreel.  Kane, Susan, and Bernstei emerging from side doorway of City Hall into a ring of pr photographers, reporters, etc.  Kane looks startled, reco for an instance, then charges down upon the photographers laying about him with his stick, smashing whatever he can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For wife two, one-time opera singing  Susan Alexander, Kane built  Chicago's Municipal Opera House.   Cost: three million dollars.   Conceived for Susan Alexander Kane,  half-finished before she divorced  him, the still unfinished Xanadu.   Cost: no man can say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still of architect's sketch with typically glorified "ren of the Chicago Municipal Opera House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glamorous shot of the almost-finished Xanadu, a magnifi fairy-tale estate built on a mountain. (1920) Then shots of its preparation. (1917) Shots of truck after truck, train after train, flashing b with tremendous noise. Shots of vast dredges, steamshovels. Shot of ship standing offshore unloading its lighters. In quick succession, shots follow each other, some  reconstructed, some in miniature, some real shots (maybe the dam projects) of building, digging, pouring concrete,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred thousand trees, twenty  thousand tons of marble, are the  ingredients of Xanadu's mountain. Xanadu's livestock: the fowl of  the air, the fish of the sea, the  beast of the field and jungle -  two of each; the biggest private  zoo since Noah.  Contents of Kane's  palace: paintings, pictures,  statues, the very stones of many  another palace, shipped to Florida  from every corner of the earth,  from other Kane houses, warehouses,  where they mouldered for years.   Enough for ten museums - the loot  of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More shots as before, only this time we see (in miniature large mountain - at different periods in its development rising out of the sands. Shots of elephants, apes, zebras, etc. being herded, unlo shipped, etc. in various ways. Shots of packing cases being unloaded from ships, from tr from trucks, with various kinds of lettering on them (Ita Arabian, Chinese, etc.) but all consigned to Charles Fost Kane, Xanadu, Florida. A reconstructed still of Xanadu - the main terrace.  A gr of persons in clothes of the period of 1917.  In their mi clearly recognizable, are Kane and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane urged his country's entry  into one war, opposed participation  in another.  Swung the election to  one American President at least,  was called another's assassin.   Thus, Kane's papers might never  have survived - had not the  President.

dialogues.speaker: SHAPED.
dialogues.text: Shots of various authentically worded headlines of Americ papers since 1895. Spanish-American War shots. (1898) A graveyard in France of the World War and hundreds of cr (1919)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old newsreels of a political campaign. Insert of a particularly virulent headline and/or cartoon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, molder of mass opinion though  he was, in all his life was never  granted elective office by the  voters of his country.  Few U.S.  news publishers have been. Few, like one-time Congressman  Hearst, have ever run for any office -  most know better - conclude with  other political observers that one  man's press has power enough for  himself.  But Kane papers were  once strong indeed, and once the  prize seemed almost his.  In 1910,  as Independent Candidate for  governor, the best elements of the  state behind him - the White House  seemingly the next easy step in a  lightning political career -

dialogues.speaker: IN POLITICS
dialogues.text: Newsreel shots of great crowds streaming into a building Madison Square Garden - then shots inside the vast audito at one end of which is a huge picture of Kane.  (1910) Shot of box containing the first Mrs. Kane and young Howa Kane, age five.  They are acknowledging the cheers of the (Silent Shot)  (1910) Newreel shot of dignitaries on platform, with Kane, along of speaker's table, beaming, hand upraised to silence the (Silent Shot)  (1910)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, suddenly - less than one  week before election - defeat!   Shameful, ignominious - defeat  that set back for twenty years the  cause of reform in the U.S., forever  cancelled political chances for  Charles Foster Kane.  Then, in the  third year of the Great  Depression...  As to all publishers,  it sometimes must - to Bennett, to  Munsey and Hearst it did - a paper  closes!  For Kane, in four short  years: collapse! Eleven Kane papers, four Kane  magazines merged, more sold,  scrapped -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newreel shot - closeup of Kane delivering a speech...  (1 The front page of a contemporary paper - a screaming head Twin phots of Kane and Susan.  (1910) Printed title about Depression. Once more repeat the map of the USA 1932-1939.  Suddenly, cartoon goes into reverse, the empire begins to shrink,  illustrating the narrator's words. The door of a newspaper office with the signs: "Closed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then four long years more - alone  in his never-finished, already  decaying, pleasure palace, aloof,  seldom visited, never photographed,  Charles Foster Kane continued to  direct his falling empire ... vainly  attempting to sway, as he once  did, the destinies of a nation  that has ceased to listen to him  ... ceased to trust him...

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF XANADU., (1940)
dialogues.text: Series of shots, entirely modern, but rather jumpy and ob bootlegged, showing Kane in a bath chair, swathed in summ rugs, being perambulated through his rose garden, a desol figure in the sunshine.  (1935)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week, death came to sit upon  the throne of America's Kubla Khan -  last week, as it must to all men,  death came to Charles Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabinent Photograph (Full Screen) of Kane as an old, old This image remains constant on the screen (as camera pull back, taking in the interior of a dark projection room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fairly large one, with a long throw to the screen.  It dark. The image of Kane as an old man remains constant on the s as camera pulls back, slowly taking in and registering  Projection Room.  This action occurs, however, only after first few lines of encuring dialogue have been spoken.  T shadows of the men speaking appear as they rise from thei chairs - black against the image of Kane's face on the sc NOTE:  These are the editors of a "News Digest" short, an the Rawlston magazines.  All his enterprises are represen in the projection room, and Rawlston himself, that great is present also and will shortly speak up. During the entire course of this scene, nobody's face is seen.  Sections of their bodies are picked out by a table a silhouette is thrown on the screen, and their faces and are themselves thrown into silhouette against the brillia slanting rays of light from the projection room. A Third Man is on the telephone.  We see a corner of his and the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at phone) Stand by.  I'll tell you if we  want to run it again. (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tough thing to do in a  newsreel.  Seventy years of a man's  life -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmur of highly salaried assent at this.  Rawlston walks camera and out of the picture.  Others are rising.  Camer during all of this, apparently does its best to follow ac and pick up faces, but fails.  Actually, all set-ups are planned very carefully to exclude the element of personal from this scene; which is expressed entirely by voices, s sillhouettes and the big, bright image of Kane himself on screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what Arthur Ellis wrote about  him in the American review?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (its owner is already  leaning across the  table, holding a  piece of paper  under the desk  light and reading  from it) Listen:  Kane is dead.  He  contributed to the journalism of  his day - the talent of a  mountebank, the morals of a  bootlegger, and the manners of a  pasha.  He and his kind have almost  succeeded in transforming a once  noble profession into a seven  percent security - no longer secure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Arthur Ellis is writing  now.  Thirty years ago, when Kane  gave him his chance to clean up  Detroit and Chicago and St. Louis,  Kane was the greatest guy in the world.  If you ask me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Foster Kane was a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then observations are made almost simultaneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves to take in his bulk outlined against the glo from the projection room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were Kane's last words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence greets this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were the last words he said  on earth?  Thompson, you've made  us a good short, but it needs  character -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motivation -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it - motivation.  What made  Kane what he was?  And, for that  matter, what was he?  What we've  just seen are the outlines of a  career - what's behind the career?   What's the man?  Was he good or  bad?  Strong or foolish?  Tragic  or silly?  Why did he do all those  things?  What was he after? (then, appreciating  his point) Maybe he told us on his death bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and maybe he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask the question anyway, Thompson! Build the picture around the  question, even if you can't answer  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (riding over him  like any other  producer) All we saw on that screen was a  big American -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the biggest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without pausing  for this) But how is he different from Ford? Or Hearst for that matter?  Or  Rockefeller - or John Doe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know people worked for Kane will  tell you - not only in the newspaper  business - look how he raised  salaries.  You don't want to forget -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take his labor record alone,  they ought to hang him up like a  dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, Thompson - a man's  dying words -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Yes, Mr. Rawlston, what were Kane's  dying words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with disgust) Rosebud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little ripple of laughter at this, which is promptly si by Rawlston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough guy, huh? (derisively) Dies calling for Rosebud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a man who might have been  President.  He's been loved and  hated and talked about as much as  any man in our time - but when he  comes to die, he's got something  on his mind called "Rosebud."   What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A racehorse he bet on once,  probably, that didn't come in -  Rosebud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  But what was the race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a short silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold this thing up for a week.   Two weeks if you have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feebly) But don't you think if we release  it now - he's only been dead four  days it might be better than if -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (decisively) Nothing is ever better than finding  out what makes people tick.  Go  after the people that knew Kane  well.  That manager of his - the  little guy, Bernstein, those two  wives, all the people who knew  him, had worked for him, who loved  him, who hated his guts - (pauses) I don't mean go through the City Directory, of course -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Third Man gives a hearty "yes-man" laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get to it right away, Mr. Rawlston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera from behind him, outlines his back against Kan picture on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll probably turn out to be a  very simple thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE:  Now begins the story proper - the seach by Thompso the facts about Kane - his researches ... his interviews the people who knew Kane. It is important to remember always that only at the very of the story is Thompson himself a personality.  Until th throughout the picture, we photograph only Thompson's bac shoulders, or his shadow - sometimes we only record his v He is not until the final scene a "character".  He is the personification of the search for the truth about Charles Kane.  He is the investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first image to register is a sign:

dialogues.speaker: TWICE NIGHTLY
dialogues.text: These words, spelled out in neon, glow out of the darknes the end of the fade out.  Then there is lightning which r a squalid roof-top on which the sign stands.  Thunder aga and faintly the sound of music from within.  A light glow from a skylight.  The camera moves to this and closes in. Through the splashes of rain, we see through the skylight into the interior of the cabaret.  Directly below us at a sits the lone figure of a woman, drinking by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medium shot of the same woman as before, finishing the dr she started to take above.  It is Susie.  The music, of c is now very loud.  Thompson, his back to the camera, move into the picture in the close foreground.  A Captain appe behind Susie, speaking across her to Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a Greek) This is Mr. Thompson, Miss  Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan looks up into Thompson's face.  She is fifty, tryin look much younger, cheaply blonded, in a cheap, enormousl generous evening dress.  Blinking up into Thompson's face throws a crink into ther mouth.  Her eyes, which she thin keeping commandingly on his, are bleared and watery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Captain) I want another drink, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low thunder from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing his chance) Right away.  Will you have  something, Mr. Thompson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring to sit  down) I'll have a highball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (so insistently as  to make Thompson  change his mind  and stand up again) Who told you you could sit down  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  I thought maybe we could have  a drink together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an awkward pause as Thompson looks from her to t Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you people let me alone? I'm minding my own business.  You  mind yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd just let me talk to you  for a little while, Miss Alexander. All I want to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here! (almost hysterical) Get out!  Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson looks at the Captain, who shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Maybe some other time -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he thought he would get a response from Susan, who thi she is looking at him steelily, he realizes his error.  H nods and walks off, following the Captain out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just not talking to anybody  from the newspapers, Mr. Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not from a newspaper exactly,  I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have come upon a waiter standing in front of a booth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Get her another highball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another double?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment,  pityingly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's plastered, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll snap out of it.  Why, until  he died, she'd just as soon talk  about Mr. Kane as about anybody.   Sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come down in a week or so and  see her again.  Say, you might be  able to help me.  When she used to  talk about Kane - did she ever  happen to say anything - about  Rosebud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosebud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson has just handed him a bill.  The Captain pockets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.  As a matter of  fact, yesterday afternoon, when it  was in all the papers - I asked  her.  She never heard of Rosebud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An excruciatingly noble interpretation of Mr. Thatcher hi executed in expensive marble.  He is shown seated on one those improbable Edwin Booth chairs and is looking down, stone eyes fixed on the camera. We move down off of this, showing the impressive pedestal which the monument is founded.  The words, "Walter Parks  Thatcher" are prominently and elegantly engraved thereon. Immediately below the inscription we encounter, in a medi shot, the person of Bertha Anderson, an elderly, manish  spinnster, seated behind her desk.  Thompson, his hat in hand, is standing before her.  Bertha is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes.  I'll take him in now. (hangs up and looks  at Thompson) The directors of the Thatcher  Library have asked me to remind  you again of the condition under  which you may inspect certain  portions of Mr. Thatcher's  unpublished memoirs.  Under no  circumstances are direct quotations  from his manuscript to be used by  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without watching whether he is following her or not, she and starts towards a distant and imposingly framed door. Thompson, with a bit of a sigh, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room with all the warmth and charm of Napolean's tomb. As we dissolve in, the door opens in and we see past Thom shoulders the length of the room.  Everything very plain, much made out of marble and very gloomy.  Illumination fr skylight above adds to the general air of expensive and  classical despair.  The floor is marble, and there is a  gigantic, mahogany table in the center of everything.  Be this is to be seen, sunk in the marble wall at the far en the room, the safe from which a guard, in a khaki uniform with a revolver holster at his hip, is extracting the jou of Walter P. Thatcher.  He brings it to Bertha as if he w the guardian of a bullion shipment.  During this, Bertha been speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the guard) Pages eighty-three to one hundred  and forty-two, Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thompson) You will confine yourself, it is  our understanding, to the chapter  dealing with Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I'm interested in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard has, by this time, delivered the precious journ Bertha places it reverently on the table before Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be required to leave this  room at four-thirty promptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.  Thompson starts to light a cigarette.  The g shakes his head.  With a sigh, Thompson bends over to rea manuscript.  Camera moves down over his shoulder onto pag manuscript. Manuscript, neatly and precisely written:

dialogues.speaker: OF 1870..."
dialogues.text: The camera has not held on the entire page.  It has been  following the words with the same action that the eye doe reading.  On the last words, the white page of the paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white of a great field of snow, seen from the angle o parlor window. In the same position of the last word in above Insert, ap the tiny figure of Charles Foster Kane, aged five (almost an animated cartoon).  He is in the act of throwing a sno at the camera.  It sails toward us and over our heads, ou scene. Reverse angle - on the house featuring a large sign readi

dialogues.speaker: INQUIRE WITHIN
dialogues.text: Charles Kane's snowball hits the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera is angling through the window, but the window-fram not cut into scene.  We see only the field of snow again, angle as in previous scene.  Charles is manufacturing ano snowball.  Now - Camera pulls back, the frame of the window appearing, and are inside the parlor of the boardinghouse.  Mrs. Kane, a about 28, is looking out towards her son.  Just as we tak in she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Be careful, Charles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calling out the  window almost on  top of this) Pull your muffler around your neck,  Charles -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Charles, deliriously happy in the snow, is oblivious this and is running away.  Mrs. Kane turns into camera an see her face - a strong face, worn and kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: think we'll have to tell him now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera now pulls back further, showing Thatcher standing a table on which is his stove-pipe hat and an imposing  multiplicity of official-looking documents.  He is 26 and might be expected, a very stuffy young man, already very  expensive and conservative looking, even in Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sign those papers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people seem to forget that I'm  the boy's father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of Kane Sr.'s voice, both have turned to him the camera pulls back still further, taking him in. Kane Sr., who is the assistant curator in a livery stable been groomed as elegantly as is likely for this meeting e since daybreak. From outside the window can be heard faintly the wild and cheerful cries of the boy, blissfully cavorting in the sn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be done exactly the way I've told Mr. Thatcher -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I want to, I can go to court. father has a right to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Mr. Kane, the certificates that  Mr.  Graves left here are made out  to Mrs.  Kane, in her name.  Hers  to do with as she pleases -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't hold with signing my  boy away to any bank as guardian just because -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I want you to stop all this  nonsense, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bank's decision in all matters  concerning his education, his place  of residence and similar subjects  will be final. (clears his throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea of a bank being the  guardian -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane has met his eye.  Her triumph over him finds  expression in his failure to finish his sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more quietly) I want you to stop all this  nonsense, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will assume full management of  the Colorado Lode - of which you,  Mrs. Kane, are the sole owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane Sr. opens his mouth once or twice, as if to say some but chokes down his opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has been reading  past Thatcher's  shoulder as he  talked) Where do I sign, Mr. Thatcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, Mrs. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sulkily) Don't say I didn't warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane lifts the quill pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, I'm asking you for the last  time - anyon'd think I hadn't been a good husband and a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane looks at him slowly.  He stops his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sum of fifty thousand dollars  a year is to be paid to yourself  and Mr. Kane as long as you both  live, and thereafter the survivor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane puts pen to the paper and signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's hope it's all for the  best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.  Go on, Mr. Thatcher -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane, listening to Thatcher, of course has had her o ear bent in the direction of the boy's voice.  Thatcher i aware both of the boy's voice, which is counter to his ow and of Mrs. Kane's divided attention.  As he pauses, Kane genteelly walks over to close the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane Jr., seen from Kane Sr.'s position at the window.  H advancing on the snowman, snowballs in his hands, droppin one knee the better to confound his adversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the rebels want a fight boys,  let's give it to 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws two snowballs, missing widely, and gets up and  advances another five feet before getting on his knees ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The terms are underconditional  surrender.  Up and at 'em!  The  Union forever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane Sr. closes the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the boy's  voice) Everything else - the principal as  well as all monies earned - is to  be administered by the bank in  trust for your son, Charles Foster  Kane, until his twenty-fifth  birthday, at which time he is to  come into complete possession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane rises and goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Mr. Thatcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher continues as she opens the window.  His voice, a before, is heard with overtones of the boy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane Jr., seen from Mrs. Kane's position at the window. now within ten feet of the snowman, with one snowball lef which he is holding back in his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't lick Andy Jackson!  Old  Hickory, that's me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fires his snowball, well wide of the mark and falls fl his stomach, starting to crawl carefully toward the snowm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nearly five, Mrs. Kane, don't you think I'd better meet the boy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane at the window.  Thatcher is now standing at her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got his trunk all packed - (she chokes a little) I've it packed for a couple of  weeks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't say anymore.  She starts for the hall day.  Kan Sr., ill at ease, has no idea of how to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've arranged for a tutor to meet  us in Chicago.  I'd have brought  him along with me, but you were so anxious to keep everything secret -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops as he realizes that Mrs. Kane has paid no attent to him and, having opened the door, is already well into hall that leads to the side door of the house.  He takes look at Kane Sr., tightens his lips and follows Mrs. Kane Kane, shoulders thrown back like one who bears defeat bra follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, in the snow-covered field.  With the snowman betwee and the house, he is holding the sled in his hand, just a to make the little run that prefaces a belly-flop.  The K house, in the background, is a dilapidated, shabby, two-s frame building, with a wooden outhouse.  Kane looks up as sees the single file procession, Mrs. Kane at its head, c toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H'ya, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing at the  snowman) See, Mom?  I took the pipe out of  his mouth.  If it keeps on snowin', maybe I'll make some teeth and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better come inside, son.  You  and I have got to get you all ready for - for -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, my name is Mr. Thatcher -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Thatcher, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Charles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes from the east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Hello, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Thatcher is going to take you  on a trip with him tonight, Charles. You'll be leaving on Number Ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the train with all the  lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goin', Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother won't be going right  away, Charles -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'm I going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to see Chicago and  New York - and Washington, maybe... Isn't he, Mr. Thatcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartily) He certainly is.  I wish I were a  little boy and going to make a  trip like that for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you comin' with us,  Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to stay here, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to live with Mr.  Thatcher from now on, Charlie!   You're going to be rich.  Your Ma  figures - that is, re - she and I  have decided that this isn't the  place for you to grow up in. You'll probably be the richest man  in America someday and you ought  to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be lonely, Charles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have a lot of good  times together, Charles...  Really  we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Charles.  Let's shake  hands. (extends his hand.   Charles continues  to look at him) Now, now!  I'm not as frightening  as all that!  Let's shake, what do  you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out for Charles's hand.  Without a word, Charl hits him in the stomach with the sled.  Thatcher stumbles a few feet, gasping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sickly grin) You almost hurt me, Charles. (moves towards him) Sleds aren't to hit people with. Sleds are to - to sleigh on.  When  we get to New York, Charles, we'll get you a sled that will -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's near enough to try to put a hand on Kane's shoulder. he does, Kane kicks him in the ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws himself on her, his arms around her.  Slowly Mr Kane puts her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Mom!  Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Charles, it's all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher is looking on indignantly, occasionally bending to rub his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Thatcher!  What the kid  needs is a good thrashing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you think, is it, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane looks slowly at Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) That's why he's going to be brought  up where you can't get at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old-fashioned railroad wheels underneath a sleeper, spinn along the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher, with a look of mingled exasperation, annoyance, sympathy and inability to handle the situation, is standi alongside a berth, looking at Kane.  Kane, his face in th pillow, is crying with heartbreaking sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom!  Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white page of the Thatcher manuscript.  We pick up th words:

dialogues.speaker: IRRESPONSIBLE."
dialogues.text: The words are followed by printed headline on "Enquirer" (as in following scene).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up on printed headline which reads:

dialogues.speaker: "ENEMY ARMADA OFF JERSEY COAST"
dialogues.text: Camera pulls back to reveal Thatcher holding the "Enquire copy, on which we read the headline.  He is standing near editorial round table around which a section of the staff including Reilly, Leland and Kane are eating lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Is that really your idea of how to  run a newspaper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to run a newspaper,  Mr. Thatcher.  I just try everything  I can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading headline  of paper he is  still holding) "Enemy Armada Off Jersey Coast."   You know you haven't the slightest  proof that this - this armada - is  off the Jersey Coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you prove it isn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein has come into the picture.  He has a cable in h hand.  He stops when he sees Thatcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bernstein, Mr. Thatcher -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Mr. Thatcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just had a wire from Cuba, Mr.  Kane - (stops, embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.  We have no  secrets from our readers.  Mr.  Thatcher is one of our most devoted  readers, Mr.  Bernstein.  He knows  what's wrong with every issue since  I've taken charge.  What's the  cable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) The food is marvelous in Cuba the  senoritas are beautiful stop I  could send you prose poems of palm  trees and sunrises and tropical  colors blending in far off  landscapes but don't feel right in  spending your money for this stop  there's no war in Cuba regards  Wheeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see!  There hasn't been a true  word -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll have to send our  friend Wheeler a cable, Mr.  Bernstein.  Of course, we'll have  to make it shorter than his, because  he's working on an expense account  and we're not.  Let me see - (snaps his fingers) Mike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a fairly tough  customer prepares  to take dictation,  his mouth still  full of food) Go ahead, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Wheeler - (pauses a moment) You provide the prose poems - I'll  provide the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the boys and girls at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rather like it myself.  Send it  right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Bernstein leave.  Kane looks up, grinning at Tha who is bursting with indignation but controls himself.  A a moment of indecision, he decides to make one last try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to see you, Charles, about  your - about the Enquirer's campaign  against the Metropolitan Transfer  Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you step into my office, Mr. Thatcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross the City Room together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should remind you,  Charles, of a fact you seem to  have forgotten.  You are yourself  one of the largest individual  stockholders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane holds the door open for Thatcher.  They come in toge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Thatcher, isn't everything  I've been saying in the Enquirer  about the traction trust absolutely  true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) They're all part of your general attack - your senseless attack - on everything and everybody who's  got more than ten cents in his  pocket.  They're -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble is, Mr. Thatcher, you  don't realize you're talking to two people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane moves around behind his desk.  Thatcher doesn't unde looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charles Foster Kane, who has                          eighty-two thousand, six hundred  and thirty-one shares of  Metropolitan Transfer - you see, I  do have a rough idea of my holdings - I sympathize with you.  Charles  Foster Kane is a dangerous  scoundrel, his paper should be run  out of town and a committee should  be formed to boycott him.  You  may, if you can form such a  committee, put me down for a  contribution of one thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Charles, my time is too valuable  for me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand - (his manner becomes  serious) I am the publisher of the Enquirer. As such, it is my duty - I'll let  you in on a little secret, it is  also my pleasure - to see to it  that decent, hard-working people  of this city are not robbed blind  by a group of money - mad pirates  because, God help them, they have  no one to look after their  interests!  I'll let you in on  another little secret, Mr. Thatcher.   I think I'm the man to do it.  You  see, I have money and property -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher doesn't understand him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't defend the interests of  the underprivileged, somebody else  will - maybe somebody without any  money or any property and that  would be too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher glares at him, unable to answer.  Kane starts to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how to tap, Mr.  Thatcher?  You ought to learn - (humming quietly,  he continues to  dance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher puts on his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happened to see your consolidated  statement yesterday, Charles.   Could I not suggest to you that it  is unwise for you to continue this  philanthropic enterprise - (sneeringly) this Enquirer - that is costing  you one million dollars a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  We did lose a million  dollars last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher thinks maybe the point has registered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expect to lost a million next year, too.  You know, Mr. Thatcher - (starts tapping  quietly) at the rate of a million a year - we'll have to close this place in  sixty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson - at the desk.  With a gesture of annoyance, he closing the manuscript. Camera arcs quickly around from over his shoulder to hold door behind him, missing his face as he rises and turns t confront Miss Anderson, who has come into the room to sho out.  Very prominent on this wall is an over-sized oil pa of Thatcher in the best Union League Club renaissance sty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have enjoyed a very rare  privilege, young man.  Did you  find what you were looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Tell me something, Miss  Anderson.  You're not Rosebud, are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you were.  Well,  thanks for the use of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hat on his head and starts out, lighting a ci as he goes.  Miss Anderson, scandalized, watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closeup of a still of Kane, aged about sixty-five.  Camer pulls back, showing it is a framed photograph on the wall Over the picture are crossed American flags.  Under it si Bernstein, back of his desk.  Bernstein, always an unders Jew, now seems even smaller than in his youth.  He is bal an egg, spry, with remarkably intense eyes.  As camera co to travel back, the back of Thompson's head and his shoul come into the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Who's a busy man?  Me?  I'm Chairman  of the Board.  I got nothing but  time ...  What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still explaining) Well, Mr. Bernstein, you were with  Mr.  Kane from the very beginning -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From before the beginning, young  fellow.  And now it's after the  end. (turns to Thompson) Anything you want to know about  him - about the paper -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -  We thought maybe, if we can  find out what he meant by that  last word - as he was dying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Rosebud?  Maybe some girl?   There were a lot of them back in  the early days, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not some girl he knew casually and  then remembered after fifty years, on his death bed -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty young, Mr. - (remembers the name) Mr. Thompson.  A fellow will  remember things you wouldn't think  he'd remember.  You take me.  One  day, back in 1896, I was crossing  over to Jersey on a ferry and as  we pulled out, there was another ferry pulling in - (slowly) - and on it, there was a girl  waiting to get off.  A white dress  she had on - and she was carrying  a white pastrol - and I only saw  her for one second and she didn't  see me at all - but I'll bet a  month hasn't gone by since that I  haven't thought of that girl. (triumphantly) See what I mean? (smiles) Well, so what are you doing about  this "Rosebud," Mr. Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling on people who knew Mr.  Kane.  I'm calling on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else you been to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I went down to Atlantic City -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie?  I called her myself the  day after he died.  I thought maybe  somebody ought to... (sadly) She couldn't even come to the  'phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why?  She was so -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else did you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else, but I've been through  that stuff of Walter Thatcher's. That journal of his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher!  That man was the biggest darn fool I ever met -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made an awful lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not trick to make an awful  lot of money if all you want is to  make a lot of money. (his eyes get  reflective) Thatcher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein looks out of the window and keeps on looking, s to see something as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never knew there was anything  in the world but money.  That kind  of fellow you can fool every day  in the week - and twice on Sundays! (reflectively) The time he came to Rome for Mr.  Kane's twenty-fifth birthday...   You know, when Mr. Kane got control  of his own money...  Such a fool like Thatcher - I tell you, nobody's business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein speaking to Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew what he wanted, Mr. Kane  did, and he got it!  Thatcher never  did figure him out.  He was hard  to figure sometimes, even for me.   Mr. Kane was a genius like he said.   He had that funny sense of humor.   Sometimes even I didn't get the  joke.  Like that night the opera  house of his opened in Chicago...   You know, the opera house he built  for Susie, she should be an opera  singer... (indicates with a  little wave of his  hand what he thinks  of that; sighing) That was years later, of course -  1914 it was.  Mrs. Kane took the  leading part in the opera, and she  was terrible.  But nobody had the  nerve to say so - not even the  critics.  Mr. Kane was a big man  in those days.  But this one fellow,  this friend of his, Branford Leland -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the sentence up in the air, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late.  The room is almost empty.  Nobody is at work the desks.  Bernstein, fifty, is waiting anxiously with a group of Kane's hirelings, most of them in evening dress overcoats and hats.  Eveybody is tense and expectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to a young  hireling; quietly) What about Branford Leland?  Has  he got in his copy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go in and ask him to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you, Mr. Bernstein? You know Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him for a  moment; then slowly) I might make him nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You and Leland and Mr. Kane - you  were great friends back in the old  days, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) That's right.  They called us the  "Three Musketeers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody behind Bernstein has trouble concealing his laug The City Editor speaks quickly to cover the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a great guy - Leland. (another little  pause) Why'd he ever leave New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he isn't saying) That's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tactless one) Wasn't there some sort of quarrel  between -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I had nothing to do with it. (then, somberly) It was Leland and Mr. Kane, and  you couldn't call it a quarrel  exactly.  Better we should forget  such things - (turning to City  Editor) Leland is writing it up from the  dramatic angle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I thought it was a good idea. We've covered it from the news  end, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the social.  How about the  music notice?  You got that in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, it's already made up.   Our Mr. Mervin wrote a small review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enthusiastic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very! (quietly) Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well - isn't that nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bernstein -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein turns. Medium long shot of Kane, now forty-nine, already quite s He is in white tie, wearing his overcoat and carrying a f opera hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hirelings rush, with Bernstein, to Kane's side.  Wide half-suppressed sensation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kane, this is a surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a nice plant here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody falls silent.  There isn't anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the show covered by every  department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly according to your  instructions, Mr. Kane.  We've got  two spreads of pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very, very casually) And the notice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at him for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's another one still to  come - the dramatic notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) It isn't finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Leland, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he said when he'll finish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't heard from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to work fast - didn't he,  Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure did, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right in there, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hireling indicates the closed glass door of a little at the other end of the City Room.  Kane takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helpless, but very  concerned) MR. KANE -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane crosses the length of the long City Room to the glas door indicated before by the Hireling.  The City Editor l at Bernstein.  Kane opens the door and goes into the offi closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland and Mr. Kane - they haven't  spoke together for ten years. (long pause; finally) Excuse me. (starts toward the  door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein comes in.  An empty bottle is standing on Lelan desk.  He has fallen over his typewriter, his face on the A sheet of paper is in the machine.  A paragraph has been Kane is standing at the other side of the desk looking do him.  This is the first time we see murder in Kane's face Bernstein looks at Kane, then crosses to Leland.  He shak him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Brad!  Brad! (he straightens,  looks at Kane;  pause) He ain't been drinking before, Mr.  Kane.  Never.  We would have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally; after a  pause) What does it say there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he written?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein looks over nearsightedly, painfully reading the paragraph written on the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Miss Susan Alexander, a pretty  but hopelessly incompetent amateur - (he waits for a  minute to catch  his breath; he  doesn't like it) - last night opened the new Chicago  Opera House in a performance of -  of -" (looks up miserably) I can't pronounce that name, Mr.  Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein looks at Kane for a moment, then looks back, to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading again) "Her singing, happily, is no concern  of this department.  Of her acting,  it is absolutely impossible to..." (he continues to  stare at the page)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a short  silence) Go on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) That's all there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane snatches the paper from the roller and reads it for  himself.  Slowly, a queer look comes over his face.  Then speaks, very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of her acting, it is absolutely  impossible to say anything except  that it represents a new low... (then sharply) Have you got that, Mr. Bernstein? In the opinion of this reviewer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserably) I didn't see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't here, Mr. Bernstein.  I'm  dictating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) I can't take shorthand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a typewriter.  I'll finish  the notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein retreats from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shot of Kane in his shirt sleeves, illuminated by a light, typing furiously.  As the camera starts to pull ev farther away from this, and as Bernstein - as narrator - to speak -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein speaking to Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finished it.  He wrote the worst  notice I ever read about the girl  he loved.  We ran it in every paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I guess Mr. Kane didn't think so  well of Susie's art anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him very  soberly) He thought she was great, Mr.  Thompson.  He really believed that.   He put all his ambition on that  girl.  After she came along, he  never really cared for himself  like he used to.  Oh, I don't blame Susie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, how could he write  that roast?  The notices in the  Kane papers were always very kind  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  He saw to that.  I tell  you, Mr. Thompson, he was a hard  man to figure out.  He had that  funny sense of humor.  And then,  too, maybe he thought by finishing  that piece he could show Leland he  was an honest man.  You see, Leland  didn't think so.  I guess he showed  him all right.  He's a nice fellow,  but he's a dreamer.  They were  always together in those early  days when we just started the  Enquirer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On these last words, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front half of the second floor constitutes one large Room.  Despite the brilliant sunshine outside, very littl it is actually getting into the room because the windows small and narrow.  There are about a dozen tables and des of the old-fashioned type, not flat, available for report Two tables, on a raised platform at the end of the room,  obviously serve the city room executives.  To the left of platform is an open door which leads into the Sanctrum. As Kane and Leland enter the room, an elderly, stout gent the raised platform, strikes a bell and the other eight  occupants of the room - all men - rise and face the new  arrivals.  Carter, the elderly gent, in formal clothes, r and starts toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, Mr. Kane, to the  "Enquirer."  I am Herbert Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Carter.  This is Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing) How do you do, Mr. Leland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the  standing reporters) Are they standing for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would be a nice gesture the new publisher -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Ask them to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may resume your work, gentlemen. (to Kane) I didn't know your plans and so I  was unable to make any preparations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't my plans myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are following Carter to his raised platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I haven't got  any.  Except to get out a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a terrific crash at the doorway.  They all turn see Bernstein sprawled at the entrance.  A roll of beddin suitcase, and two framed pictures were too much for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you would come here a moment, please, Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein rises and comes over, tidying himself as he com

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Carter, this is Mr. Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein is my general manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frigidly) How do you do, Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a private office here,  haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The delivery wagon driver has now appeared in the entranc with parts of the bedstead and other furniture.  He is lo about, a bit bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating open  door to left of  platform) My little sanctum is at your  disposal.  But I don't think I  understand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to live right here. (reflectively) As long as I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a morning newspaper, Mr. Kane. After all, we're practically closed  twelve hours a day - except for  the business offices -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one of the things I think  must be changed, Mr. Carter.  The  news goes on for twenty-four hours  a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, in his shirt sleeves, at a roll-top desk in the San is working feverishly on copy and eating a very sizeable at the same time.  Carter, still formally coated, is seat alongside him.  Leland, seated in a corner, is looking on detached, amused.  The furniture has been pushed around a Kane's effects are somewhat in place.  On a corner of the Bernstein is writing down figures.  No one pays any atten to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not criticizing, Mr. Carter,  but here's what I mean.  There's a  front page story in the "Chronicle," (points to it) and a picture - of a woman in  Brooklyn who is missing.  Probably  murdered. (looks to make sure  of the name) A Mrs. Harry Silverstone.  Why  didn't the "Enquirer" have that  this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) Because we're running a newspaper,  Mr.  Kane, not a scandal sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane has finished eating.  He pushes away his plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still hungry, Brad.  Let's go  to Rector's and get something  decent. (pointing to the  "Chronicle" before  him) The "Chronicle" has a two-column  headline, Mr. Carter.  Why haven't  we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no news big enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the headline is big enough, it  makes the new big enough.  The  murder of Mrs. Harry Silverstone -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) As a matter of fact, we sent a man  to the Silverstone home yesterday  afternoon. (triumphantly) Our man even arrived before the  "Chronicle" reporter.  And there's  no proof that the woman was murdered - or even that she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling a bit) The "Chronicle" doesn't say she's  murdered, Mr. Carter.  It says the  neighbors are getting suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) It's not our function to report  the gossip of housewives.  If we  were interested in that kind of  thing, Mr. Kane, we could fill the  paper twice over daily -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) That's the kind of thing we are  going to be interested in from now  on, Mr. Carter.  Right now, I wish  you'd send your best man up to see  Mr. Silverstone.  Have him tell  Mr.  Silverstone if he doesn't  produce his wife at once, the  "Enquirer" will have him arrested. (he gets an idea) Have him tell Mr. Silverstone he's  a detective from the Central Office. If Mr. Silverstone asks to see his  badge, your man is to get indignant  and call Mr. Silverstone an  anarchist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loudly, so that the neighbors can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Mr. Kane, I can't see the function of a respectable newspaper -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane isn't listening to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein looks up from his figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just made a shocking discovery. The "Enquirer" is without a  telephone.  Have two installed at  once!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ordered six already this morning! Got a discount!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at Leland with a fond nod of his head at Berns Leland grins back.  Mr. Carter, meantime, has risen stiff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mr. Kane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
