dialogues.text: That'll be all today, Mr. Carter. You've been most understanding. Good day, Mr. Carter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter, with a look that runs just short of apoplexy, lea the room, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Mr. Carter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) What makes those fellows think  that a newspaper is something rigid,  something inflexible, that people are supposed to pay two cents for -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Three cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Two cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein lifts his head and looks at Kane.  Kane gazes b at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping on the  paper) This is all figured at three cents  a copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-figure it, Mr. Bernstein, at  two cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs and puts  papers in his pocket) All right, but I'll keep these  figures, too, just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for dinner, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Leland, if Mr. Kane, he should  decide to drop the price to one  cent, or maybe even he should make  up his mind to give the paper away  with a half-pound of tea - you'll  just hold him until I get back,  won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not guaranteeing a thing, Mr. Bernstein.  You people work too  fast for me!  Talk about new brooms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about brooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a saying, Mr. Bernstein.  A  new broom sweeps clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT -
dialogues.text: The ground floor witht he windows on the street - of the  "Enquirer."  It is almost midnight by an old-fashioned cl on the wall.  Grouped around a large table, on which are locked forms of type, very old-fashioned of course, but t to the period - are Kane and Leland in elegant evening cl Bernstein, unchanged from the afternoon, and Smathers, th composing room foreman, nervous and harassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's impossible, Mr. Kane.  We  can't remake these pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These pages aren't made up as I  want them, Mr. Smathers.  We go to  press in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to crack up) The "Enquirer" has an old and  honored tradition, Mr. Kane...   The "Enquirer" is not in competition  with those other rags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be publishing such rags, that's all I wish.  Why, the  "Enquirer" - I wouldn't wrap up  the liver for the cat in the  "Enquirer" -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged) Mr. Kane, I must ask you to see to  it that this - this person learns  to control his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been a newspaperman my whole  life and I don't intend - (he starts to sputter) - if it's your intention that I  should continue to be harassed by  this - this - (he's really sore) I warn you, Mr. Kane, it would go  against my grain to desert you  when you need me so badly - but I  would feel obliged to ask that my  resignation be accepted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is accepted, Mr. Carter, with  assurances of my deepest regard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Kane, I meant -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane turns his back on him, speaks again to the composing foreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Let's remake these pages, Mr.  Smathers.  We'll have to publish a  half hour late, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though Kane  were talking Greek) We can't remake them, Mr. Kane.   We go to press in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane sighs, unperturbed, as he reaches out his hand and s the forms off the table onto the floor, where they scatte into hundreds of bits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can remake them now, can't  you, Mr. Smathers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smather's mouth opens wider and wider.  Bradford and Bern are grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the types 've been reset and  the pages have been remade according  to the way I told you before, Mr. Smathers, kindly have proofs pulled  and bring them to me.  Then, if I  can't find any way to improve them again - (almost as if  reluctantly) - I suppose we'll have to go to  press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out of the room, followed by Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smathers) In case you don't understand, Mr. Smathers - he's a new broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture is mainly occupied by a large building, on th roof of which the lights spell out the word "Enquirer" ag the sunrise.  We do not see the street or the first few s of this building, the windows of which would be certainly illuminated.  What we do see is the floor on which is loc the City Room.  Over this scene, newboys are heard sellin Chronicle, their voices growing in volume. As the dissolve complete itself, camera moves toward the lighted window - the window of the Sanctrum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newsboys are still heard from the street below - fain but very insistent. Kane's office is gas-lit, of course, as is the rest of th Enquirer building. Kane, in his shirt sleeves, stands at the open window loo out.  The bed is already made up.  On it is seated Bernst smoking the end of a cigar.  Leland is in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRONICLE!  CHRONICLE!  H'YA - THE  CHRONICLE - GET YA!  CHRONICLE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, taking a deep breath of the morning air, closes the and turns to the others.  The voices of the newsboys, nat are very much fainter after this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be on the street soon, Charlie -  another ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his  watch) It's three hours and fifty minutes late - but we did it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland rises from the chair, stretching painfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a tough day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wasted day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Wasted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously) Charlie?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just made the paper over four times today, Mr. Kane.  That's all -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed the front page a  little, Mr. Bernstein.  That's not  enough - There's something I've  got to get into this paper besides  pictures and print -  I've got to  make the "New York Enquirer" as  important to New York as the gas  in that light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What're you going to do, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at him for a minute with a queer smile of happ concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Declaration of Principles - (he says it with  quotes around it) Don't smile, Brad - (getting the idea) Take dictation, Mr. Bernstein -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't take shorthand, Mr. Kane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll write it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane grabs a piece of rough paper and a grease crayon.  S down on the bed next to Bernstein, he starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over his  shoulder) You don't wanta make any promises,  Mr. Kane, you don't wanta keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he writes) These'll be kept. (stops for a minute  and reads what he  has written; reading) I'll provide the people of this  city with a daily paper that will  tell all the news honestly. (starts to write  again; reading as  he writes) will also provide them -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the second sentence you've started with "I" -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) People are going to know who's  responsible.  And they're going to get the news - the true news - quickly and simply and  entertainingly. (he speaks with  real conviction) And no special interests will be  allowed to interfere with the truth  of that news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Leland for a minute and goes back to his writ reading as he writes. Bernstein has risen and crossed to one side of Kane.  The both stand looking out.  Leland joins him on the other si Their three heads are silhouetted against the sky.  Lelan head is seen to turn slightly as he looks into Kane's fac camera very close on this - Kane turns to him and we know eyes have met, although their faces are almost in sillhou Bernstein is still smoking a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front page of the "Enquirer" shows big boxed editorial wi heading:

dialogues.speaker: MY PRINCIPLES
dialogues.text: Camera continues pulling back and shows newspaper to be o top of a pile of newspapers.  As we draw further back, we four piles, and as camera contines to pull back, we see s piles and go on back until we see a big field of "Enquire piles of "Enquirers" - all 26,000 copies ready for distri A wagon with a huge sign on its side reading

dialogues.speaker: "ENQUIRER
dialogues.text: passes through foreground, and we wipe to: A pile of "Enquirers" for sale on a broken down wooden bo a street corner, obviously a poor district.  A couple of fall on the pile. The stoop of a period door with old-fashioned enamel milk and a bag of rolls.  Across the sidewalk before this, mov the shadow of an old-fashioned bicycle with an enormous f wheel.  A copy of the "Enquirer" is tossed on the stoop. A breakfast table - beautiful linen and beautiful silver everything very expensive, gleaming in the sunshine.  Int silver newspaper rack there is slipped a copy of the "Enq Here, as before, the boxed editorial reading MY PRINCIPLE DECLARATION BY CHARLES FOSTER KANE, is very prominent on front page. The wooden floor of a railroad station, flashing light an dark as a train behind the camera rushes by.  On the floo there is tossed a bound bundle of the "New York Enquirer" the Declaration of Principles still prominent. Rural Delivery - a copy of the "Enquirer"s being put into showing state distribution. The railroad platform again.  We stay here for four image On each image, the speed of the train is faster and the p of the "Enquirer" are larger.  On the first image, we mov to hold on the words "CIRCULATION - 31,000."  We are this for the next pile which reads 40,000; the next one which 55,000, and the last which is 62,000.  In each instance, bundles of newspapers are thicker and the speed of the mo train behind the camera is increased. The entire montage above indicated is accompanied by a  descriptive complement of sound - the traffic noises of N York in the 1890's; wheels on cobblestones and horses' ho bicycle bells; the mooning of cattle and the crowing of r (in the RFD shot), and in all cases where the railroad pl is used - the mounting sound of the railroad train. The last figure "62,000" opposite the word "CIRCULATION" the "Enquirer" masthead changes to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle up to wall of building - a painter on a cradle is p the last zero to the figure "62,000" on an enormous sign  advertising the "Enquirer."  It reads:

dialogues.speaker: THE ENQUIRER THE PEOPLE'S NEWSPAPER CIRCULATION 62,000
dialogues.text: Camera travels down side of building - takes in another b on which there is a sign which reads:

dialogues.speaker: READ THE ENQUIRER AMERICA'S FINEST CIRCULATION 62,000
dialogues.text: Camera continues to travel down to sidewalk in front of t Chronicle office.  The Chronicle office has a plateglass in which is reflected traffic moving up and down the stre also the figures of Kane, Leland and Bernstein, who are m peanuts. Inside the window, almost filling it, is a large photogra the "Chronicle" staff, with Reilly prominently seated in center.  A sign over the photo reads: EDITORIAL AND EXECU STAFF OF THE NEW YORK CHRONICLE.  A sign beneath it reads GREATEST NEWSPAPER STAFF IN THE WORLD.  The sign also inc the "Chronicle" circulation figure.  There are nine men i photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at the  sign - happily) Sixty-two thousand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looks pretty nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the  Chronicle Building) Let's hope they like it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Chronicle Building that  sign is the biggest thing you can  see - every floor guaranteed -  let's hope it bothers them - it  cost us enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the  sign over the  photograph in the  window) Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Chronicle" is a good newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good idea for a newspaper. (reading the figures) Four hundred sixy thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, with them fellows - (referring to the  photo) - it's no trick to get circulation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) You know how long it took the  "Chronicle" to get that staff  together?  Twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, smiling, lights a cigarette, at the same time looki into the window.  Camera moves in to hold on the photogra nine men, still holding the reflection of Kane's smiling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine men, arrayed as in the photograph, but with Kane bea in the center of the first row.  The men, variously with  mustaches, beards, bald heads, etc. are easily identified being the same men, Reilly prominent amongst them. As camera pulls back, it is revealed that they are being  photographed - by an old-type professional photographer, box, black hood and all - in a corner of the room.  It is at night.  Desks, etc. have been pushed against the wall. Running down the center of the room is a long banquet tab at which twenty diners have finished their meals.  The el remaining at their seats - these include Bernstein and Le are amusedly watching the photographic ceremonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographic subjects rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden thought) Make up an extra copy and mail it  to the "Chronicle."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckling and beaming, he makes his way to his place at t head of the table.  The others have already sat down.  Ka gets his guests' attention by rapping on the table with a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the "Enquirer"!  This  has, I think, been a fitting welcome to those distinguished journalists - (indicates the eight  men) Mr. Reilly in particular - who are  the latest additions to our ranks. It will make them happy to learn  that the "Enquirer's" circulation  this morning passed the two hundred  thousand mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred and one thousand, six  hundred and forty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of you - new and old -  You're  all getting the best salaries in  town.  Not one of you has been  hired because of his loyalty.   It's your talent I'm interested  in.  That talent that's going to  make the "Enquirer" the kind of  paper I want - the best newspaper  in the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, I think you'll agree we've  heard enough about newspapers and  the newspaper business for one  night.  There are other subjects  in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his two fingers in his mouth and lets out a shril whistle.  This is a signal.  A band strikes up a lively d of the period and enters in advance a regiment of very  magnificent maidens, as daringly arrayed as possible in t chorus costumes of the day.  The rest of this episode wil planned and staged later.  Its essence is that Kane is ju healthy and happy young man having a wonderful time. As some of the girls are detached from the line and made partners for individual dancing -

dialogues.speaker: CIRCULATION 274,321
dialogues.text: Dissolve just completes itself - the image of Kane dancin with a girl on each arm just disappears as camera pans do off the Temple Bldg. in the same action as the previous s scene.  There is a new sign on the side of the building b It reads:

dialogues.speaker: READ THE ENQUIRER GREATEST STAFF IN THE WORLD
dialogues.text: Camera continues panning as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of various scenes, between the years 1891-1900. The scenes indicate the growth of the "Enquirer" under th impulse of Kane's personal drive.  Kane is shown, thus, a various activities: Move down from the sign: READ THE ENQUIRER  GREATEST STAF THE WORLD to street in front of saloon with parade passin (boys going off to the Spanish-American War)-  A torchlig parade with the torches reflected in the glass window of saloon - the sound of brass band playing "It's a Hot Time In the window of the saloon is a large sign or poster "RE

dialogues.speaker: THE MAINE"
dialogues.text: INSERT:  Remington drawing of American boys, similar to t parade above, in which "Our Boys" in the expeditionary ha are seen marching off to war. Back of observation car.  Shot of Kane congratulating Ted Roosevelt (the same shot as in the News Digest - without  flickering). The wooden floor of the railroad platform again - a bundl "Enquirers" - this time an enormous bundle - is thrown do and the moving shadows of the train behind the camera ind that it is going like a bat out of hell.  A reproduction Kane and Teddy shaking hands as above is very prominent i frame and almost hogs the entire front page.  The headlin indicates the surrender of Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cartoon, highly dramatic and very involved as to content lousy with captions, labels, and symbolic figures, the mo gruesome and recognizable - "Capitalistic Greed."  This c is almost finished and is on a drawing board before which Kane and the artist himself.  Kane is grinning over some  suggestion he has made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cartoon finished and reproduced on the editorial page the "Enquirer" - in quite close, with an editorial and se faces of caps shown underneath.  The entire newspaper is with an angry gesture and thrown down into an expensive-l wastebasket (which is primarily for ticker tape) tape is  pouring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cartoonist and Kane working on comic strip of "Johnny the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floor of room -  Two kids on floor, with newspaper spread looking at the same comic strip. Kane's photographic gallery with photographers, stooges, Kane himself in attendance on a very hot-looking item of period.  A sob sister is interviewing this hot number and is arranging her dress to look more seductive.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: The hot number reproduced and prominently displayed and c almost half a page of the "Enquirer."  It is being read i barber shop and is seen in an over-shoulder shot of the m who is reading it.  He is getting a shine, a manicure, an haircut.  The sob-sister caption over the photograph reve

dialogues.speaker: "I DIDN'T KNOW WHAT I WAS DOING, SAYS DANCER. EVERYTHING
dialogues.text: RED."  An oval photograph of the gun is included in the l out of the pretty lady with a headline which says: "DEATH

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Shot of Kane, in evening clothes, in obvious position of grabbing camera from photographer.  Before him rages a te tenement fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT:  Headline about inadequacy of present fire equipm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final shot of a new horse-drawn steam engine roaring arou street corner (Stock).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black pattern of iron bars.  We are in a prison cell. door is opened and a condemned man, with priest, warden a the usual attendants, moves into foreground and starts up hall past a group which includes phtographers, Kane's sob sister, and Kane.  The photographers take pictures with a flash of old-fashioned flash powder.  The condemned man i foreground (in silhouette) is startled by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copy of the "Enquirer" spread out on a table.  A big la of the execution story includes the killer as photographe Kane's photographers, and nearby on the other page there large picture of the new steam fire engine (made from the shot) with a headline indicating that the "Enquirer" has its campaign for better equipment.  A cup of coffee and a doughnut are on the newspaper, and a servant girl - over shoulder we see the paper - is stirring the coffee. The Beaux Art Ball.  A number of elderly swells are jamme into a hallway.  Servants suddenly divest them of their f overcoats and wraps, revealing them to be in fancy dress  costume, pink fleshings, etc., the effect to be very surp very lavish and very very ridiculous.  We see, among othe Mr. Thatcher himself (as Ben Hur) ribbon around, his bald and all.  At the conclusion of this tableau, the image fr and we pull back to show it reproduced on the society pag the "New York Enquirer." Over the "Enquirer"'s pictorial version of the Beaux Art is thrown a huge fish - then coffee grounds - altogether pretty repulsive sight. The whole thing is bundled up and thrown into a garbage c Extreme close-up of the words: "OCCUPATION - JOUNALIST." Camera pulls back to show passport open to the photograph which shows Kane, registering birth, race, and nationalit Passport cover is closed, showing it to be an American pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As camera pulls back over shoulder of official, taking in Leland, and Bernstein, we see the bustle and noise of dep ocean liner.  Behind the principles can be seen an enormo plain sign which reads: "FIRST CLASS."  From offstage can heard the steward's cry, indispensable in any Mercury  production, the old familiar cry, "All Ashore That's Goin Ashore!" - gongs, also blasts of the great whistle and al rest of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, Mr. Kane.  Everything  in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane and Leland and Bernstein start up the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Have a good rest, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But please, Mr. Kane, don't buy  any more paintings.  Nine Venuses  already we got, twenty-six Virgins -  two whole warehouses full of stuff -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise not to bring any more  Venuses and not to worry - and not  to try to get in touch with any of the papers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All ashore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and to forget about the new  feature sections - and not to try  to think up and ideas for comic  sections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All ashore that's going ashore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane leaves Leland and Bernstein midway up gangplank, as rushes up to it, calling back with a wave:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, gents! (at the top of the  gangplank, he turns  and calls down) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling down to  them) You don't expect me to keep any of  those promises, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band on deck strikes up "Auld Lang Syne."  Bernstein an Leland turn to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you, Mr. Leland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start down the gangplank together.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENQUIRER BUILDING
dialogues.text: The pattern of telegraph wires, dripping with rain, throu which we see the same old building but now rendered fairl remarkable by tremendous outline sign in gold which reads NEW YORK DAILY ENQUIRER."  A couple of lights show in the building.  We start toward the window where the lights sh as we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light in the window in the former shot was showing be the letter "E" of the Enquirer sign.  Now the letter "E" even larger than the frame of the camera.  Rain drips  disconsolately off the middle part of the figure.  We see through this and through the drizzle of the window to  Bernstein's desk where he sits working under a blue shade light.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: Same setup as before except that it is now late afternoon late in the winter of the year.  The outline "E" is hung icicles which are melting, dripping despairingly between and Mr. Bernstein, still seated at his desk - still worki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same setup as before except that it is spring.  Instead o sad sounds of dripping rain or dripping icicles, we hear melancholy cry of a hurdy-gurdy in the street below.  It spring and through the letter "E" we can see Bernstein wo at his desk.  Pigeons are gathering on the "E" and on the Bernstein looks up and sees them.  He takes some crumbs f his little homemade lunch which is spread out on the desk him, carries them to the windows and feeds the pigeons, l moodily out on the prospect of spring on Park Row.  The b eat the crumbs - the hurdy-gurdy continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same setup again, it is now summer.  The window was h open before .. now it's open all the way and Bernstein ha gone so far as to take off his coat.  His shirt and his  celluloid collar are wringing wet.  Camera moves toward t window to tighten on Bernstein and to take in the City Ro behind him, which is absolutely deserted.  It is clear th there is almost nothing more for Bernstein to do.  The hu gurdy in the street is playing as before, but a new tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beach on Coney Island. Bernstein in a rented period bathing suit sits alone in t sand, reading a copy of the "Enquirer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole floor is now a City Room.  It is twice its form size, yet not too large for all the desks and the people them.  The windows have been enlarged, providing a good d more light and air.  A wall calendar says September 9th. Kane and Bernstein enter and stand in the entrance a mome Kane, who really did look a bit peaked before, is now cle eyed and tanned.  He is wearing new English clothes.  As come into the room, Bernstein practically walking sideway doing nothing but beaming and admiring Kane, quelling lik mother at the Carnegie Hall debut of her son.  Seeing and recognizing Kane, the entire staff rises to its feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the  staff; with a smile) Ask them to sit down, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, everybody - for heaven's  sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The order is immediately obeyed, everybody going into bus of feverish activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then, tonight, we go over  everything thoroughly, eh?   Especially the new papers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We certainly do.  Vacation's over - starting right after dinner.  But right now - that lady over there - (he indicates a  woman at the desk) - that's the new society editor, I  take it?  You think I could  interrupt her a moment, Mr.  Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Oh, I forgot - you've been  away so long I forgot about your joking -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails after Kane as he approaches the Society Editor' desk.  The Society Editor, a middle-aged spinster, sees h approaching and starts to quake all over, but tries to pr she isn't aware of him.  An envelope in her hand shakes  violently.  Kane and Bernstein stop at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Townsend -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Townsend looks up and is so surprised to see Bernste with a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Kane, Miss Townsend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Townsend can't stick to her plan.  She starts to ris but her legs are none too good under her.  She knocks ove tray of copy paper as she rises, and bends to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very hesitatingly  and very softly) Miss Townsend -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of his voice, she straightens up.  She is ve close to death from excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been away for several months,  and I don't know exactly how these  things are handled now.  But one  thing I wanted to be sure of is  that you won't treat this little  announcement any differently than  you would any other similar  announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her an envelope.  She has difficulty in holding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Read it, Miss Townsend.  And  remember - just the regular  treatment!  See you at nine o'clock,  Mr. Bernstein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane leaves.  Bernstein looks after him, then at the pape Miss Townsend finally manages to open the envelope.  A pi of flimsy paper, with a few written lines, is her reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Norton  announce the engagement of their  daughter, Emily Monroe Norton, to  Mr.  Charles Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to read it) Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Norton announce -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fluttering - on  top of him) She's - she's the niece of - of  the President of the United States -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding proudly) know.  Come on, Miss Townsend - From the window, maybe we can get  a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her by the hand and leads her off. Angle toward open window.  Bernstein and Miss Townsend, b to camera, rushing to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle downward - what Bernstein and Miss Townsend se from the window. Kane is just stepping into an elegant barouch, drawn up a curb, in which sits Miss Emily Norton.  He kisses her ful the lips before he sits down.  She acts a bit taken aback because of the public nature of the scene, but she isn't annoyed.  As the barouche starts off, she is looking at h adoringly.  He, however, has turned his head and is looki adoringly at the "Enquirer."  He apparently sees Bernstei Miss Townsed and waves his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein and Miss Townsend at window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl like that, believe me, she's  lucky!  Presiden't niece, huh!   Say, before he's through, she'll  be a Presiden't wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Townsend is now dewey-eyed.  She looks at Bernstein, has turned away, gazing down at the departing couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front page of the "Enquirer."  Large picture of the young Kane and Emily - occupying four columns - very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein and Thompson.  As the dissolve comes, Bernstein voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way things turned out, I don't  need to tell you - Miss Emily Norton  was no rosebud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't end very well, did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It ended - (a slight pause) Then there was Susie - that ended,  too. (shrugs, a pause;  then looking up  into Thompson's  eyes) guess he didn't make her very happy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was thinking - that  Rosebud you're trying to find out  about -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that was something he lost.   Mr. Kane was a man that lost -  almost everything he had - (a pause) You ought to talk to Bradford  Leland.  He could tell you a lot.   I wish I could tell you where Leland  is, but I don't know myself.  He  may be out of town somewhere - he  may be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you'd like to know, Mr. Bernstein, he's at the Huntington  Memorial Hospital on 180th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say!  Why I had no idea -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing particular the matter with him, they tell me.  Just - (controls himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just old age. (smiles sadly) It's the only disease, Mr. Thompson,  you don't look forward to being  cured of. (pauses) You ought to see Mr. Leland.   There's a whole lot of things he  could tell you - if he wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot - Thompson.  He is tilted back in a chair whic seems to be, and is, leaning against a chimney.  Leland's is heard for a few moments before Leland is seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get to my age, young man,  you don't miss anything.  Unless  maybe it's a good drink of bourbon. Even that doesn't make much  difference, if you remember there  hasn't been any good bourbon in  this country for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera has pulled back, during above speech, revealing th Leland, wrapped in a blanket, is in a wheel chair, talkin Thompson.  They are on the flat roof of a hospital.  Othe people in wheel chairs can be seen in the background, alo with a nurse or two.  They are all sunning themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Leland, you were -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't happen to have a cigar,  do you?  I've got a young physician -  must remember to ask to see his  license - the odds are a hundred  to one he hasn't got one - who  thinks I'm going to stop smoking...   I changed the subject, didn't I?   Dear, dear!  What a disagreeable  old man I've become.  You want to  know what I think of Charlie Kane?   Well - I suppose he has some private  sort of greatness.  But he kept it  to himself. (grinning) He never - gave himself away -  He never gave anything away.  He just - left you a tip.  He had a generous  mind.  I don't suppose anybody  ever had so many opinions.  That  was because he had the power to  express them, and Charlie lived on  power and the excitement of using  it -  But he didn't believe in anything except Charlie Kane.  He  never had a conviction in his life.   I guess he died without one -   That must have been pretty  unpleasant.  Of course, a lot of  us check out with no special  conviction about death.  But we do  know what we're leaving ... we  believe in something. (looks sharply at  Thompson) You're absolutely sure you haven't  got a cigar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind -  Bernstein told you  about the first days at the office,  didn't he?  Well, Charlie was a  bad newspaper man even then.  He  entertained his readers, but he  never told them the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could remember something that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can remember everything.  That's  my curse, young man.  It's the  greatest curse that's ever been  inflicted on the human race.  Memory -   I was his oldest friend. (slowly) As far as I was concerned, he  behaved like swine.  Maybe I wasnt'  his friend.  If I wasn't, he never  had one.  Maybe I was what nowadays you call a stooge -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party (previously shown in the Bernstein sequence). We start this sequence toward the end of the former one, from a fresh angle, holding on Leland, who is at the end the table.  Kane is heard off, making a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of you has been hired  because of his loyalty.  It's your  talent I'm interested in.  That  talent that's going to make the  "Enquirer" the kind of paper I  want - the best newspaper in the  world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.  During above, Bernstein has come to Leland's s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it wonderful?  Such a party!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone causes Bernstein to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, I think you'll agree we've  heard enough about newspapers and  the newspaper business for one  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The above speeches are heard under the following dialogue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Leland) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bernstein, these men who are  now with the "Enquirer" - who were  with the "Chronicle" until yesterday - weren't they just as devoted to  the "Chronicle" kind of paper as  they are now to - our kind of paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  They're like anybody else. They got work to do.  They do it. (proudly) Only they happen to be the best  men in the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing his speech) There are other subjects in the  world -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane whistles.  The band and the chorus girls enter and h breaks loose all around Leland and Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a minute) Do we stand for the same things  that the "Chronicle" stands for,  Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Certainly not.  So what's that got  to do with it?  Mr. Kane, he'll  have them changed to his kind of  newspapermen in a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.  There's always a chance,  of course, that they'll change Mr. Kane - without his knowing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane has come up to Leland and Bernstein.  He sits down n to them, lighting a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, are we going to  war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our readers are, anyway, I don't  know about the rest of the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) It'll be our first foreign war in  fifty years, Brad.  We'll cover it  the way the "Hickville Gazette"  covers the church social!  The  names of everybody there; what  they wore; what they ate; who won  the prizes; who gave the prizes - (gets excited) I tell you, Brad, I envy you. (quoting) By Bradford Leland, the "Enquirer's" Special Correspondent at the Front. I'm almost tempted -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is no Front, Charlie. There's a very doubtful civil war. Besides, I don't want the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Brad, all right - you  don't have to be a war correspondent  unless you want to - I'd want to. (looking up) Hello, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie, a very handsome madam has walked into the pictur stands behind him.  She leans over and speaks quietly in ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything the way you want it,  dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) If everybody's having fun, that's  the way I want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some other little girls coming over -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Charles, I tell you there is no  war!  There's a condition that  should be remedied - but between  that and a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) How would the "Enquirer" look with  no news about this non-existent  war - with Benton, Pulitzer and  Heart devoting twenty columns a  day to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do it only because you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) And I do it because they do it,  and they do it - it's a vicious  circle, isn't it? (rises) I'm going over to Georgie's, Brad - you know, Georgie, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over Kane's next  lines) Glad to meet you, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you about Brad, Georgie. He needs to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some ships with wonderful wines  have managed to slip through the  enemy fleet that's blockading New York harbor - (grins) Georgie knows a young lady whom  I'm sure you'd adore - wouldn't  he, Georgie?  Why only the other  evening I said to myself, if Brad  were only here to adore this young  lady - this - (snaps his fingers) What's her name again?

dialogues.speaker: INT. GEORGIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Georgie is introducing a young lady to Branford Leland. sound track we hear piano music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right on cue from  preceding scene) Ethel - this gentlemen has been  very anxious to meet you -  This  is Ethel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera pans to include Kane, seated at piano, with girls  gathered around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!  Play the song about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a song about Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane has broken into "Oh, Mr. Kane!" and Charlie and the start to sing.  Ethel leads the unhappy Leland over to th group.  Kane, seeing Leland and taking his eye, motions t professor who has been standing next to him to take over. professor does so.  The singing continues.  Kane rises an crosses to Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Brad. (draws him slightly  aside) I've got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I've got a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to be a war  correspondent - how about being a  dramatic critic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely, but not  gushing; seriously) I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane starts quietly to dance in time to the music.  Lelan smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start tomorrow night.  Richard  Carl in "The Spring Chicken." (or supply show) I'll get us some girls.  You get  tickets.  A drama critic gets them  free, you know. (grins) Rector's at seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling) It doesn't make any difference  about me, but one of these days  you're going to find out that all  this charm of yours won't be enough -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has stopped dancing) You're wrong.  It does make a  difference to you -  Rector's,  Brad? (starts to dance  again) Come to think of it, I don't blame  you for not wanting to be a war  correspondent.  You won't miss  anything.  It isn't much of a war. Besides, they tell me there isn't  a decent restaurant on the whole  island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland, Kane, two young ladies at Rector's.  Popular musi heard over the soundtrack.  Everybody is laughing very, v hard at something Kane has said.  The girls are hysterica Kane can hardly breathe.  As Leland's laughter becomes mo and more hearty, it only increases the laughter of the ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As told by Bernstein.  Kane is calling down to Leland and Bernstein (as before).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't expect me to keep any of  those promises, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band on deck strikes up "Auld Lang Syne" and further sh shore conversation is rendered unfeasible. Bernstein and Leland on deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to Leland) Do you, Mr. Leland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slight pause.  They continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Leland, why didn't you go to  Europe with him?  He wanted you to.  He said to me just yesterday -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted him to have fun - and  with me along -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Bernstein.  Bernstein looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bernstein, I wish you'd let me ask you a few questions, and answer  me truthfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I always?  Most of the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bernstein, am I a stuffed shirt?   Am I a horse-faced hypocrite?  Am  I a New England school-marm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you thought I'd answer different  from what Mr. Kane tells you -  well, I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good naturedly) You're in a conspiracy against me,  you two.  You always have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against me there should be such a  conspiracy some time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses.  "Auld Lang Syne" can still be heard from the of the department steamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a hopeful  look in his eyes) Well, he'll be coming back in  September.  The Majestic.  I got  the reservations.  It gets in on  the ninth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September the ninth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland puts his hand in his pocket, pulls out a pencil an small engagement book, opens the book and starts to write Leland's pencil writing on a page in the engagement book to September 9: "Rector's - 8:30 p.m."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front page "Enquirer."  Large picture of the young couple Kane and Emily - occupying four columns - very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland and Thompson.  Leland is speaking as we dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to go to dancing school  with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson had handed Leland a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a letter from her lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud from  the letter) David, Grobleski & Davis -  My dear Rawlston - (looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rawlston is my boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  I know about Mr. Rawlston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows the first Mrs. Kane  socially -  That's the answer we  got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) I am in receipt of your favor of  yesterday.  I beg you to do me the  courtesy of accepting my assurance  that Mrs. Whitehall cannot be  induced to contribute any more  information on the career of Charles  Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has authorized me to state on previous occasions that regards their brief marriage as a distateful episode in h life that she prefers to forget.  With assurances of the esteem - Leland hands the paper back to Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief marriage!  Ten years! (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he in love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He married for love - (a little laugh) That's why he did everything.   That's why he went into politics.   It seems we weren't enough.  He  wanted all the voters to love him,  too.  All he really wanted out of  life was love.  That's Charlie's  story - it's the story of how he  lost it.  You see, he just didn't  have any to give.  He loved Charlie  Kane, of course, very dearly - and  his mother, I guess he always loved  her.  As for Emily - well, all I  can tell you is Emily's story as  she told it to me, which probably  isn't fair - there's supposed to  be two sides to every story - and  I guess there are.  I guess there's more than two sides -

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: Newspaper - Kane's marriage to Emily with still of group White House lawn, same setup as early newsreel in News Di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screaming headline: OIL SCANDAL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline reading: KANE TO SEE PRESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big headline on "Enquirer" front page which reads: KANE T

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Under this, one of those big box signed editorials, typic Kane, illustrated, on subject of the power of the preside expressed in about nine different cases of type, and illu by a cartoon of the White House, on which camera tightens we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This scene is shot so as never to show the President - or least never his face.  There is present the President's  Secretary, sitting on one side of the desk, intently taki notes.  Kane is on his feet, in front of the desk, tense glaring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the unanimous opinion of my  Cabinent - in which I concur -  that the proposed leases are in  the best interests of the  Governement and the people. (pauses) You are not, I hope, suggesting  that these interests are not  indentical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not suggesting anything, Mr. President!  I've come here to tell  you that, unless some action is  taken promptly - and you are the  only one who can take it - the oil  that is the property of the people  of this country will be turned  over for a song to a gang of high- pressure crooks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) I must refuse to allow you to  continue in this vein, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) It's the only vein I know.  I tell  the facts the way I see them.  And any man that knows that facts -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the facts, Mr. Kane.  And I  happen to have the incredible  insolence to differ with you as to  what they mean. (pause) You're a man of great talents, Mr.  Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you have political  ambitions.  Unfortunately, you  seem incapable of allowing any  other opinion but your own -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (building to a frenzy) I'm much obliged, Mr. President,  for your concern about me.  However,  I happen to be concerned at this  moment with the matter of extensive  oil lands belonging to the people  of the United States, and I say  that if this lease goes through,  the property of the people of the  United States goes into the hands  of -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You've made your point perfectly  clear, Mr. Kane.  Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretary rises.  Kane, with every bit of will power  remotely at his disposal to control what might become an  hysterical outburst, manages to bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, Reilly, Leland and a composing room Foreman, in wor clothes, bending over a table with several forms of type. They are looking, at this moment, at a made-up headline - Kane's back is in the way ... so we can't read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, Mr. Kane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reilly glances at his wrist watch and makes a face.  Kane as he notices this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Let her slide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, and we can now read the headline. Insert of the headline, which reads: "OIL THEFT BECOMES L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here follows a quick montage (presently to be worked out) no more than four or five images in which the President, means of cartoons, editorials, headlines (all faithfully  reproduced from period yellow journalism) is violently at The montage ends on the word TREASON.  The music cuts. A hand reaches in a side pocket which contains a newspape recognizably the "Enquirer."  The hand removes a gun.  Th is shot.  Many arms seize the hand which is pulled up - g still firing.  As the arm is raised in the air, we see th the other arms holding the arm and struggling with it are uniformed, and we see the White House beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News ticker which is spelling out the words: "ASSASSINATE

NOTE:  Under the following - a down shot, below the "Enqu shows a crowd forming, looking angrily up toward the came Crowd noises on the soundtrack under music. A hand snatches the ticker tape away and as the image of crowd dissolves out, we pull back to show:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ticker tape is in Reilly's hand.  Reilly has a phone his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks bad for us, Mr. Kane.  How  shall we handle it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane in shirtsleeves at phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a news story!  Get it on the  street!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline under "Enquirer" masthead which reads:

dialogues.speaker: "PRESIDENT ASSASSINATED"
dialogues.text: Newsboy is crying the headline at the same time.  We pull to show him and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is in tight on a box which contains Emily and  distinguished elderly ladies and gentlemen, obviously fam and friends.  On the soundtrack, very limpid opera music. Another elderly gent, in white tie but still wearing an  overcoat, comes into the box and whispers to Emily.  He h copy of the "Enquirer" in his hand.  Emily rises.  He sho the paper to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angry crowd seen from the window of Kane's office.  Th make a deep threatening sound which is audible during the following scene.  Across the heads of the crowd are two g squares of light from the windows above them.  One of the disappears as the blind is pulled.  As the dissolve compl itself, the second square of light commences to reduce in and then the entire street is cut off by a blind which Le pulls down, covering the entire frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff standing around, worried to death, in their  shirtsleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Reilly) Take dictation -  Front page  editorial -  "This afternoon a  great man was assassinated.  He  was the President of the United  States -"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're the one who  should call him a great man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  Well - nobody's a great  man in your estimation until he's  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Maybe we'd better wait for more  word on the President's condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking at  Leland) What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may recover -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still holding on  Leland) What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steadily) Yesterday morning you called the  President a traitor.  What do you  think that crowd is doing down  there?  They think you murdered  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the crackpot who did it  had a copy of the "Enquirer" in  his pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and that copy of the "Enquirer"  said the President should be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said treason was a capital offense punishable by death -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've said a lot of things about  the President in the last few  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're true!  Everything I said! Witholding that veto was treason!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (riding over him) Oil belonging to the people of the  United States was leased out for a  song to a gang of high-pressure crooks -  Nobody can blame me  because -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out that window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane stops - looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are the people of the United States, and they are blaming you - Oh, I know it doesn't make any  sense, but at least you can learn  a lesson from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snarling) What lesson?  Not to expose fraud  when I see it?  Not to fight for  the right of the people to own  their own property? (he turns to Reilly) Run it the way I said, Reilly -  "This afternoon a great man was  assassinated -"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!  Now you're not making  sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I don't have to.  I run a newspaper  with half a million readers and  they're getting a martyred president  this morning with their breakfast. I can't help that.  Besides, they  all know I'm married to his niece.   I've got to think of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to think of Emily -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a silence) I'd like to talk to you about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland looks back at Kane, is conscious of the boys stand around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish your editorial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland walks out in to the City Room.  More staff members shirt sleeves in a state of panic.  Leland goes to his de takes out a bottle, pours himself a very stiff drink.  A opens.  A Policeman enters with Bernstein.  Bernstein is battered.  The boys crowd around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'm all right, Mr. Leland.  Only  there was some fellows out front  that thought they ought to take  things up with me.  I learned 'em! Didn't I, officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) You sure did -  Say, the  Commissioner said I was to stand  by and protect Mr. Kane until  further orders, no matter how he  felt about it.  Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing his drink) In there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hadn't come along and  protected me when you did, I'd  have killed them fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring himself  another drink) Go and get yourself washed up, Mr. Bernstein. (he looks his face  over thoroughly) There doesn't seem to be an serious  injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me.  But you will let that  cop go home with Mr. Kane, won't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernstein leaves the picture with sympathetic attendance. Leland finishes his second drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle is finished.  The door in the Sanctrum opens. and the others leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go) Goodnight, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane stands in the door, waiting for Leland.  Leland gets and moves toward the office - goes in, sits down across f Kane at the desk.  An uncomfortable pause.  Then Kane smi ingratiatingly.  Leland tries to cope with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all - (he can't go on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not cruelly -  genuinely kind) What's wrong, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I will not write a  good review of a play because  somebody paid a thousand dollars  for an advertisement in the  "Enquirer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently - opening  the door) That's just a little promotion  scheme.  Nobody expects you - (calling) Mike, will you try and get Mr.  Leland some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane turns back to Leland.  Leland doesn't look up at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, it's just no go.  We can't  agree anymore.  I wish you'd let  me go to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be transferred to the  new paper.  You've been saying  yourself you wish you had somebody  to - (he is heartsick,  inarticulate) That's not what I wanted to talk  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane goes around behind the desk and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I'll do, Brad - I'll get drunk, too - maybe that'll  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that won't help.  Besides, you  never get drunk.  I wanted to talk  about you and Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at Leland sharply before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at  him) She's going to leave you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Brad.  We've  just had word that the President  is out of danger. (ruefully) It seems I didn't kill him after  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his eye) She was going to leave you anyway -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's going south next week with  the child.  As far as anybody's to  know, it's a holiday.  When they  get back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Brad, you are drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I am.  She wants full custody  of the child no matter what happens. If you won't agree to that, she'll  apply for a divorce regardless of  the President's wishes.  I can't  tell her she's wrong, because she  isn't wrong -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is she leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's very hard for  him to say all  this) She hasn't any friends left sine  you started this oil business, and  she never sees you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think the "Enquirer"  shouldn't have campaigned against  the oil leases?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating) You might have made the whole thing  less personal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer from Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't just that the President  was her uncle - everyone she knows,  all the people she's been brought  up with, everything she's ever  been taught to believe is important -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no answer from Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason why this - this savage personal note -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The personal note is all there is  to it.  It's all there ever is to  it.  It's all there every is to  anything!  Stupidity in our  government, complacency and self- satisfaction and unwillingness to  believe that anything done by a  certain class of people can be  wrong - you can't fight those things  impersonally.  They're not  impersonal crimes against people.   They're being done by actual persons -  with actual names and positions  and - the right of the American  people to own their own country is  not an academic issue, Brad, that  you debate - and then the judges  retire to return a verdict and the  winners give a dinner for the  losers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost convince me. (rising) I'm just drunk enough to tell you  the truth.  I have to be a little  drunk for that because I'm a coward.   You know that.  That's why you  keep me around. (smiles) You only associate with your  inferiors, Charlie.  I guess that's  why you ran away from Emily.   Because you can't stand the company  of your equals.  You don't like to  admit they exist - the other big  people in your world are dead. I told you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at Leland, but Leland can't be stopped now.  H speaks very quietly - no poison in his voice - no persona indignation - as though he were explaining the nature of disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk about the people of the  United States as though they  belonged to you.  When you find  out they don't think they are,  you'll lose interest.  You talk  about giving them their rights as  though you could make a present of  liberty.  Remember the working  man?  You used to defend him quite  a good deal.  Well, he's turning  into something called organized  labor and you don't like that at  all.  And listen, when your precious  underprivileged really get together -  that's going to add up to something  bigger than - than your privilege  and then I don't know what you'll  do - sail away to a desert island,  probably, and lord it over the  monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (looking down) Now, will you let me go to Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little smile) You're not going to like it in  Chicago.  They wind comes howling  in from the lake.  And there's practically no opera season at all - and the Lord only knows whether they've ever heard of Lobster  Newburg -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. (he won't be charmed  out of his duty) What are you going to do about  Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face hardning  a little) Nothing - if she dosen't love me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland has risen.  He speaks as he turns away, starting t the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want love on your own terms, don't you, Charlie - (he stops - his  back turned to  Kane) Love according to your own rules. And if anything goes wrong and  you're hurt - then the game stops,  and you've got to be soothed and  nursed, no matter what else is  happening - and no matter who else  is hurt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simpler than that, Brad.  A  society girl can't stand the gaff,  that's all.  Other things are  important to her - social position,  what they're saying on the front  porches at Southampton, is it going  to be embarrassing to meet somebody or the other at dinner -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland has turned, taking his eye again.  Now Kane stops smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can leave me.  As a matter of  fact, I've already left her.  Don't  worry, Brad - I'll live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with all his charm) Hey, Brad!  I've been analyzed an  awful lot tonight - let's have  another brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland shakes his head.  Kane lifts his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To love on my terms.  Those are  the only terms anybody knows ...   his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, Leland, and a couple of policemen make their way ou the front toward a hansom cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You moiderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rock is thrown.  It hits Leland on the face.  A little flows.  Kane doesn't see it at first.  Then when he's in hansom cab, he turns and notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland has a handkerchief to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I wish you'd go home to Emily. She'll be pretty upset by all this - She still loves you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd, pushed by the cops, retreats in the background still hard by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still want to be transferred  to the other paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning out of the  hansom cab) Well, you've been getting a pretty  low salary here in New York.  It  seems to me that the new dramatic  critic of our Chicago paper should  get what he's worth. (almost as a question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with handkerchief  still attached to  his face) I couldn't possibly live on as  little as that, Charlie.  We'll  let the salary stay where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hansom cab starts up.  We hold on Leland's face as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is in bed, a damp cloth over her temples.  Kane is  standing at the foot of the bed.  The baby's bed is in a of the room.  The baby's nurse is standing near the crib, nurse for Emily is near her.  Kane is looking fixedly on who is staring tiredly at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the nurse) Excuse us a moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse looks at Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peremptorily) I said, excuse us a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse, unwilling, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been talking to Leland.  Emily - You can't leave me now - not now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't what it would do to my  changes in politics, Emily -  That  isn't it -  They were talking of  running me for governor, but now, of course, we'll have to wait - It isn't that, Emily -  It's just - the president is your uncle and  they're saying I killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That story about the murderer having  a copy of the "Enquirer" in his  pocket - the "Chronicle" made that  up out of whole cloth -  Emily,  please - He's going to be all right,  you know, he's going to recover - (bitterly) If it will make you any happier,  we had nine pages of advertising  cancelled in the first mail this  morning.  Bernstein is afraid to  open any more letters.  He -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops.  He sees that he's getting no place with Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) What do you expect me to do?  What in the world -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for her to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think - (she can't continue) Those threatening letters, can they really -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits up and looks at the crib.  She almost continues look at the crib, with almost unseeing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) They won't do anything to Junior,  darling. (contemptuously) Anonymous letter writers -   I've  got guards in front of the house, and I'm going to arrange -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning her face  toward him) Please don't talk any more, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is about to say something, but bites his lips instea Emily keeps staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they heard from father yet? Has he seen -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to tell you, Emily. The President's going to be all  right.  He had a comfortable night. There's no danger of any kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods several times.  There is an uncomforable silen Suddenly there is a cry from the crib.  Emily leaps from bed and rushes to him.  She bends over the crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Here I am, darling...  Darling!...   Darling, it's all right...  Mother's  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily - you musn't leave me now - you can't do that to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't hurt you, darling. Mother's with you!  Mother's looking  after you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, unwanted, ignored, looks on.  Tightening his lips, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the desk light, Kane is seen working with his usual  intensity,  Reilly standing beside him at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll withdraw support completely. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Leland sent back that check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made it out to him last week  after he left for Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, the bonus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was for twenty-five thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is perplexed and worried, but we can see in a moment mind will be on something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sent it back torn up - all torn  up into little bits, and he enclosed  something else -  I can't make it  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane doesn't answer.  Reilly goes on.  He has brought out piece of paper and is reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says here, "A Declaration of Principles" - (he still reads) "I will provide the people of this  city with a daily paper that will tell all the news honestly" -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane has looked up sharply.  Reilly, sensing his look, st reading and meets his eye.  Slowly, Kane reaches out his Reilly hands him the piece of paper.  Without reading it, tears it up, throws it into the wastebasket at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening of the final great rally.  These shots remind of and are identical with and supplementary to the "News scenes earlier.  The vast auditorium with a huge picture Kane, cheering crowds, etc.  Emily and Junior are to be s in the front of a box.  Emily is tired and wears a forced on her face.  Junior, now aged nine and a half, is eager, eyed and excited.  Kane is just finishing his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no secret that I entered  upon this campaign with no thought  that I could be elected Governor  of this state!  It is now no secret  that every straw vote, every  independent pole, shows that I  will be elected.  And I repeat to  you - my first official act as  Governor will be to appoint a  special District Attorney to arrange  for the indictment, prosecution  and conviction of Boss Edward G.  Rogers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific screaming and cheering from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Speaker's Platform.  Numerous officials and civic lea are crowding around Kane.  Cameramen take flash photograp with old-fashioined flash powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great speech, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pompous) One of the most notable public  utterances ever made by a candidate in this state -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, gentlemen.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up and notices that the box in which Emily and t boy were sitting is now empty.  He starts toward the rear the platform, through the press of people, Reilly approac him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wonderful speech, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane pats him on the shoulder as he walks along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got word from Buffalo, Mr. Kane.  They're going to throw you  the organization vote - and take a  chance maybe you'll give them a break -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is said almost inquiringly, as if he were hoping tha Kane would give him some assurance that McDonald is not m a mistake.  There is no answer from Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an independent ticket there's  never been anything like it!  If  the election were held today, you'd  be elected by a hundred thousand  votes - and every day between now  and November 7th is just going to  add to your majority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is very pleased.  He continues with Reilly slowly th the crowd - a band playing off.  Bernstein joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does seem too good to be true,  doesn't it, Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rogers isn't even pretending.  He  isn't just scared anymore.  He's  sick.  Frank Norris told me last  night he hasn't known Rogers to be  that worried in twenty-five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's beginning to dawn on  Mr. Rogers that I mean what I say. With Mr. Rogers out of the way,  Reilly, I think we may really begin  to hope for a good government in  this state. (stopping) Well, Mr. Bernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
