dialogues.text: (clearly not meaning  it) It's wonderful, Mr. Kane.   Wonderful.  Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  I do.  I mean, since you're  running for Governor - and you  want to be elected -  I think it's  wonderful you're going to be  elected.  Only - (interrupts himself) -  Can I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way I look at it - (comes out with it) -  You want to know what I really  think would be wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane indicates he is to proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're running for Governor  and going to be elected - my idea  is how wonderful it would be if  you don't run at all and don't get  elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Junior are standing, waiting for Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Pop Governor yet, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, Kane appears, with Reilly and several other me Kane rushes toward Emily and Junior, as the men politely Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Butch!  Did you like your  old man's speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Pop!  I was in a box.  I  could hear every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you! (he has his arm  around Junior's  shoulder) Good night, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are good nights.  Kane's car is at the curb and he to walk toward it with Junior and Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sending Junior home in the car, Charles - with Oliver -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd arranged to go home with  you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a call I want you to make  with me, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it can't. (she bends down and  kisses Junior) Good night, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver is holding the rear door open as Emily guides in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as car starts to  drive off) What's this all about, Emily?   I've had a very tiring day and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may not be about anything at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab has pulled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I insist on being told exactly  what you have in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to - (she looks at a  slip of paper in  her hand) - 185 West 74th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane's reaction indicates that the address definitely mea something to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wish, you can come with  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and she enters the cab.  He follows her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane and Emily.  He looks at her, in search of some kind enlightenment.  Her face is set and impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane and Emily, in front of an apartment door.  Emily is  pressing the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea you had this flair  for melodrama, Emiliy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily does not answer.  The door is opened by a maid, who recognizes Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Kane, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter, Emily first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is first a tiny reception room, through which an op door shows the living room.  Kane and Emily enter from th hallway and cross to the living room.  As they enter, Sus rises from a chair.  The other person  in the room - a bi heavyset man, a little past middle age - stays where he i leaning back in his chair, regarding Kane intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault, Charlie.  He  made me send your wife a note. He said I'd - oh, he's been saying  the most terrible things, I didn't know what to do...  I - (she catches sight  of Emily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Kane. (he rises) I don't suppose anybody would  introduce us.  Mrs. Kane, I am  Edward Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? (pauses) I came here - and I made Mr. Kane  come with me... (she consults the  note in her hand  without reading it  again) because I recieved this note -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made Miss - Miss Alexander send  you the note.  She was a little unwilling at first - (he smiles grimly) but she did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you the things he  said, Charlie.  You haven't got any idea -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on Rogers) Rogers, I don't think I will  postpone doing something about you  until I'm elected. (he starts toward  him) To start with, I'll break your  neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not giving way an  inch) Maybe you can do it and maybe you  can't, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles! (he stops to look  at her) Your - your breaking this man's neck - (she is clearly  disgusted) would scarcely explain this note - (glancing at the  note) Serious consequences for Mr. Kane - (slowly) for myself, and for my son.  What does this note mean, Miss -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) I'm Susan Alexander. (pauses) I know what you think, Mrs. Kane, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) What does this note mean, Miss  Alexander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know, Mrs. Kane.  She  just sent it - because I made her  see it wouldn't be smart for her  not to send it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you don't know, Emily, this - this gentleman - (he puts a world of  scorn into the  word) is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a gentleman, Mrs. Kane,  and your husband is just trying to  be funny calling me one.  I don't  even know what a gentleman is. (tensely, with all  the hatred and  venom in the world) You see, my idea of a gentleman,  Mrs.  Kane - well, if I owned a  newspaper and if I didn't like the  way somebody else was doing things -  some politican, say - I'd fight  them with everything I had.  Only  I wouldn't show him in a convict  suit, with stripes - so his children  could see the picture in the paper.   Or his mother. (he has to control  himself from hurling  himself at Kane) It's pretty clear - I'm not a  gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cheap, crooked grafter - and your concern for your children and your mother -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say, Mr. Kane.  Only  we're talking now about what you  are.  That's what the note is about,  Mrs. Kane.  Now I'm going to lay  all my cards on the table.  I'm  fighting for my life.  Not just my  political life.  My life.  If your husband is elected governor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be elected governor. And the first thing I'm going to do -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him finish, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm protecting myself every way I  know how, Mrs. Kane.  This last  week, I finally found out how I  can stop your husband from being  elected.  If the people of this  state learn what I found out this  week, he wouldn't have a chance to -  he couldn't be elected Dog Catcher.   Well, what I'm interested in is  seeing that he's not elected.  I  don't care whether they know what  I know about him.  Let him keep  right on being the Great, Noble,  Moral - (he stresses the  world) Champeen of the people.  Just as  long as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I understand, Mr. Rogers,  but wonder if - (she leaves her  sentence unfinished)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't blackmail me, Rogers,  you can't -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Charlie, he said, unless you  withdrew your name -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the chance I'm willing to  give you, Mr. Kane.  More of a  chance than you'd give me.  Unless  you make up your mind by tomorrow  that you're so sick that you've  got to go away for a year or two - Monday morning every paper in this  State will carry the story I'm  going to give them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane starts to stare at him intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What story, Mr. Rogers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story about him and Miss  Alexander, Mrs. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily looks at Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no story.  It's all lies. Mr. Kane is just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan) Shut up! (to Kane) I've had a dozen men doing nothing  but run this thing down - we've  got evidence enough to - well, the  evidence would stand up in any  court of law.  You want me to give  you the evidence, Mr. Kane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do anything you want to do. The people of this state can decide  which one of us to trust.  If you  want to know, they've already  decided.  The election Tuesday'll  be only -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane, I'm not asking you to believe me.  I'd like to show you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to show me anything,  Mr. Rogers.  I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather Mr. Kane withdrew without  having to get the story published. Not that I care about him.  But  I'd be better off that way - (he pauses) - and so would you, Mrs. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me? (to Kane) He said my name'd be dragged through  the mud.  He said everywhere I'd  go from now on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There seems to be only one decision  you can make, Charles.  I'd say  that it has been made for you. (pauses) I suppose the details can be  arranged tomorrow, Mr. Rogers.   About the statements by the doctors -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely mad, Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I'm going to let  this blackmailer intimidate me, do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what else you can do,  Charles.  If he's right - and the papers publish this story he has -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they'll publish it all right. But that's not going to stop me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, this - this story - doesn't  concern only you.  I'll be in it,  too, won't I? (quickly) And Junior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming a bit) I suppose so, but - I'm not afraid  of the story.  You can't tell me that the voters of this state -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in the voters  of this state right now.  I am  interested in - well, Junior, for  one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!  If they publish this story -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't.  Goodnight, Mr. Rogers. (she starts out) There's nothing more to be said,  Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  Are you coming,  Charles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.  He starts to work himself into a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one person in the  world to decide what I'm going to  do - and that's me.  And if you think - if any of you think -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You decided what you were going to  do, Charles - some time ago. (she looks at Susan) You can't always have it your own  way, regardless of anything else  that may have happened. (she sighs) Come on, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on!  Get out!  I can fight this  thing all alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making a bigger fool of  yourself than I thought you would,  Mr. Kane.  You're licked.  Why  don't you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on him) Get out!  I've got nothing to talk  to you about.  If you want to see  me, have the Warden write me a  letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see! (he starts toward  the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) Charlie, you're just excited.  You don't realize -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what I'm doing. (he is screaming) Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Charles, if you don't listen to reason, it may be too late -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late for what?  Too late for you and this - (he can't find the  adjective) this public thief to take the love  of the people of this state away  from me?  Well, you won't do it, I  tell you.  You won't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, there are other things to  think of. (a sly look comes  into her eyes) Your son - you don't want him to read in the papers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too late now, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushes to the door  and opens it) Get out, both of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushes to him) Charlie, please don't -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waiting here for? Why don't you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out.  Rogers stops as he gets directly in front Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the greatest fool I've ever  known, Kane.  If it was anybody  else, I'd say what's going to happen  to you would be a lesson to you.   Only you're going to need more  than one lesson.  And you're going  to get more than one lesson. (he walks past Kane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about me.  I'm  Charles Foster Kane.  I'm no cheap,  crooked politician, trying to save  himself from the consequences of his crimes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera angling toward Kane from other end of the hall.  R and Emily are already down the hall, moving toward foregr Kane in apartment doorway background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams louder) I'm going to send you to Sing Sing,  Rogers.  Sing Sing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is trembling with rage as he shakes his fist at Roge back.  Susan, quieter now, has snuggled into the hollow o shoulder as they stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Chronicle" front page with photograph (as in the "Ne Digest") revealing Kane's relations with Susan.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: Front page of "Chronicle" - Headline which reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front page of "Enquirer" - Headline which reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is opening the door for Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Brad -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses.  Leland comes in.  Emily closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I sent for you, Brad - didn't -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago is pretty close to New York nowadays - only twenty hours -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't have anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at him and we know that there isn't anybody el the world for her to smile at.  She's too grateful to tal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are all the returns in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland puts his hat unconsciously on his coat by the news

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland takes the newspaper out of his pocket and hands it her.  She takes it.  We see the headline, not an insert, it registers.  It reads: "Fraud at Polls."  Emily is look at the paper with unseeing eyes, and a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Almost two to one -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised he got the votes he  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should anyone vote for him?   He's made it quite clear to the  people what he thinks of them. Children - to be told one thing  one day, something else the next,  as the whim seizes him.  And they're  supposed to be grateful and love  and adore him - because he sees to  it that they get cheap ice and  only pay a nickel in the street  cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, you're being - a little  unfair -  You know what I think of  Charles' behavior - about your personal lives -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any personal lives  for people like us.  He made that very clear to me nine years ago - If I'd thought of my life with Charles as a personal life, I'd have left him then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: know that, Emily -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on top of Leland) Maybe I should have - the first  time he showed me what a mad dog  he really was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the cue "dog") Emily, you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, I'm -  I'm not an old woman yet -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's - all over -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Know it is, Brad -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's paying for it, Emily.  Those  returns tonight - he's finished. Politically - (he thinks) - socially, everywhere, I guess. don't know about the papers, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're asking me to sympathize  with him, Brad, you're wasting  your time. (pauses) There's only one person I'm sorry for, as a matter of fact.  That - that shabby little girl.  I'm really  sorry for her, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front page Chicago "Enquirer," with photograph proclaimin that Susan Alexander opens at new Chicago Opera House in  "Thais," as in "News Digest." On soundtrack during above we hear the big, expectant mur of an opening night audience and the noodling of the orch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is just inside the curtain, angling upstage. see the set for "Thais" - the principals in place - stage managers, stage hands, etc., and in the center of all thi an elaborate costume, looking very small and very lost, i Susan.  She is almost hysterical with fright.  Maids, sin teacher, and the rest are in attendance.  Her throat is s Applause is heard at the opening of the shot, and now the orchestra starts thunderously.  The curtain starts to ris the camera with it - the blinding glare of the foots move Susan's body and hits her face.  She squints and starts t sing.  Camera continues on up with the curtain, up past S up the full height of the proscenium arch and then on up the gridiron into a world of ropes, brick walls and hangi canvas - Susan's voice still heard - but faintly.  The ca stops at the top of the gridiron as the curtain stops.  T typical stage hands fill the frame.  They are looking dow the stage below.  Some of the reflected light gleams on t faces.  They look at each other.  One of them puts his ha his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland, as in the same scene in the Bernstein sequence, i sprawled across his typewriter, his head on the keys.  Th paper is gone from the roller.  Leland stirs and looks up drunkenly, his eyes encountering Bernstein, who stands be him (also as in the previous scene).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland makes a terrific effort to pull himself together. straightens and reaches for the keys - then sees the pape gone from the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it - where's my notice? I've got to finish it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mr. Kane is finishing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane?  Charlie? (painfully, he rises  to his feet) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During all this, the sound of a typewriter has been heard a busy typewriter.  Leland's eyes follow the sound.  Slow registers Kane in the City Room beyond.  This is almost t same shot as in the previous Bernstein story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, in white tie and shirt sleeves, is typing away at a machine, his fingers working briskly and efficiently, his seen by the desk light before him, set in a strange half- Leland stands in the door of his office, staring across a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose he's fixing it up - I  know I'd never get that through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to his side) Mr. Kane is finishing your piece  the way you started it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland turns incredulously to Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's writing a roast like you wanted it to be - (then suddnely -  with a kind of  quiet passion rather  than a triumph) - I guess that'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland picks his way across the City Room to Kane's side. Kane goes on typing, without looking up.  After a pause, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know we were speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane stops typing, but doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, we're speaking, Brad - you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts typing again, the expression on his face doesn' change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson and Leland on the roof, which is now deserted. getting late.  The sun has just about gone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's about all there is - and I'm getting chills.  Hey, nurse! (pause) Five years ago, he wrote from that place of his down South - (as if trying to  think) - you know.  Shangri-la?  El Dorado? (pauses) Sloppy Joe's?  What's the name of  that place?  You know...  All right.   Xanadu.  I knew what it was all  the time.  You caught on, didn't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess maybe I'm not as hard to  see through as I think.  Anyway, I  never even answered his letter. Maybe I should have.  I guess he  was pretty lonely down there those  last years.  He hadn't finished it  when she left him - he never  finished it - he never finished  anything.  Of course, he built it  for her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  He was disappointed  in the world.  So he built one of  his own -  An absolute monarchy - It was something bigger than an  opera house anyway - (calls) Nurse! (lowers his voice) Say, I'll tell you one thing you  can do for me, young fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your way out, stop at a cigar  store, will you, and send me up a  couple of cigars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mr. Leland.  I'll be glad  to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nurse appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready to go in now.  You know  when I was a young man, there was  an impression around that nurses  were pretty.  It was no truer then than it is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let me take your arm, Mr.  Leland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testily) All right, all right. (he has begun to  move forward on  the Nurse's arm;  turning to Thompson) You won't forget, will you, about  the cigars?  And tell them to wrap  them up to look like toothpaste,  or something, or they'll stop them  at the desk.  That young doctor I  was telling you about, he's got an  idea he wants to keep me alive.

dialogues.speaker: TWICE NIGHTLY
dialogues.text: glows on the dark screen as in the previous sequence earl in the script.  Behind the lights and through them, we se nasty early morning.  Camera as before, moves through the of the sign and down on the skylight, through which is se Susan at her regular table,  Thompson seated across from Very faintly during this, idle piano music playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Thompson are facing each other.  The place is a deserted.  Susan is sober.  On the other side of the room somebody is playing a piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want to handle the whole  thing - ask questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather you just talked.   Anything that comes into your mind -  about yourself and Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want to hear a lot of  what comes into my mind about myself  and Mr. Charlie Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a toothache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was thiry years ago - and I  still remember that toothache. Boy!  That toothache was just  driving me crazy...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT -
dialogues.text: Susan, aged twenty, neatly but cheaply dressed in the sty the period, is leaving the drug store.  It's about 8 o'cl at night.  With a large, man-sized handkerchief pressed t cheek, she is in considerable pain.  The street is wet - a recent rain. She walks a few steps towards the middle of the block, an stand it no longer.  She stops, opens a bottle of Oil of that she has in her hand, applies some to her finger, and her gums. She walks on, the pain only a bit better.  Four or five h farther along, she comes to what is clearly her own doorw a shabby, old four-story apartment house.  She turns towa the doorway, which is up a tiny stoop, about three steps. As she does so, Kane, coming from the opposite direction, bumps into her and turns to his left to avoid her.  His s bumps hers and she turns.  As she does so, Kane, forced t change his course, steps on the loose end of a plank whic covers a puddle in the bad sidewalk.  The plank rises up cracks him on the knee, also covering him with mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopping up and  down and rubbing  his knee) Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, taking her handkerchief from her jaw, roars with  laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bites his lip and rubs his knee again.  Susan tries to control her laughter, but not very successfully.  Kane gl at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, mister - but you do  look awful funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the pain returns and she claps her hand to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toothache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been rubbing his clothes with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got some on your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If these sidewalks were kept in  condition - instead of the money going to some cheap grafter -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan starts to laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's funny now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are.  You look like you've  been making mud pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of her smile, the pain returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no Venus de Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to the  downstair window) If you want to come in and wash  your face -  I can get you some  hot water to get that dirt off your trousers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan starts, with Kane following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in moderate disorder.  The Mansbach gas lights are o It's not really a classy room, but it's exactly what you' entitled to in 1910, for $5.00 a week including breakfast There is a bed, a couple of chairs, a chiffonier, and a f personal belongings on the chiffonier.  These include a  photograph of a gent and lady, obviously Susan's parents, a few objets d'art.  One, "At the Japanese Rolling Ball G at Coney Island," and - perhaps this is part of the Japan loot - the glass globe with the snow scene Kane was holdi his hand in the first sequence. Susan comes into the room, carrying a basin, with towels her arm.  Kane is waiting for her.  She doesn't close the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by way of  explanation) My landlady prefers me to keep  this door open when I have a  gentleman caller. (starts to put the  basin down) She's a very decent woman. (making a face) Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane rushes to take the basin from her, putting it on the chiffonier.  To do this, he has to shove the photograph t side of the basin.  Susan grabs the photograph as it is a to fall over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you should be more careful. That's my ma and pa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  They live here, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  They've passed on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again she puts her hand to her jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the soap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane fishes the soap out of the water.  It is slippery, h and slips out of his hand, hitting him in the chest befor falls to the floor.  Susan laughs as he bends over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to wash  his hands) You're very easily amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always like to see the funny  side of things.  No sense crying  when you don't have to.  And you're  so funny.  Looking at you, I forget  all about my toothache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face distorts in pain again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay here all night chasing  your pain away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) I know...  But you do look so silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, with soaped hands, has rubbed his face and now cann open his eyes, for fear of getting soap in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the towel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the chiffonier.  Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubs his face dry) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on her way to closet) I've got a brush in the closet.   As soon as the mud on your trousers  is all dry - you just brush it  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get these streets fixed, if  it's the last thing I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan comes out of the closet.  She holds out the brush w her left hand, her right hand to her jaw in real distress

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the brush) You are in pain, aren't you, you  poor kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan can't stand it anymore and sits down in a chair, be over, whimpering a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing himself) Wish there was something I could -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops and thinks.  Susan, her face averted, is still t hard not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an idea, young lady. (there is no response) Turn around and look at me. (there is still no  response) I said, turn around and look at  me, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, Susan turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see anybody wiggle  both his ears at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a second for Susan to adapt herself to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch closely! (he wiggles his  ears) It took me two solid years at the  finest boys' school in the world  to learn that trick.  The fellow  who taught me is President of  Venezuela now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still wiggling his ears as Susan starts to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it!  Smile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan smiles, very broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closeup of a duck, camera pulls back showing it to be a  shadowgraph on the wall, made by Kane, who is now in his sleeves.  It is about an hour later than preceding sequen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitatingly) A chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But you're close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rooster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting farther away all  the time.  It's a duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Kane.  I know this  takes a lot of nerve, but - who  are you?  I mean - I'm pretty  ignorant, guess you caught on to  that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks squarely at  her) You really don't know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That is, I bet it turns out  I've heard your name a million  times, only you know how it is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you like me, don't you?  Even  though you don't know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been wonderful!  I can't  tell you how glad I am you're here,  I don't know many people and - (she stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know too many people.   Obviously, we're both lonely. (he smiles) Would you like to know where I was  going tonight - when you ran into  me and ruined my Sunday clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't run into you and I bet  they're not your Sunday clothes. You've probably got a lot of  clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if defending  himself from a  terrible onslaught) I was only joking! (pauses) This evening I was on my way to the Western Manhattan Warehouses - in search of my youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, my mother died, too - a  long time ago.  Her things were  put into storage out west because  I had no place to put them then. I still haven't.  But now I've  sent for them just the same.  And  tonight I'd planned to make a sort  of sentimental journey - (slowly) - to the scenes of my youth - my  childhood, I suppose - to look  again at - (he changes mood  slightly) and now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane doesn't finish.  He looks at Susan.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I?  Well, let's see.  Charles  Foster Kane was born in New Salem, Colorado in eighteen six - (he stops on the  word "sixty" -  obviously a little  embarrassed) I run a couple of newspapers.  How  about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old did you say you were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very bright) I didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you did.  If you  had, I wouldn't have asked you  again, because I'd have remembered. How old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty old.  I'll be twenty-two in  August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her  silently for a  moment) That's a ripe old age -  What do  you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work at Seligman's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be a singer. (she thinks for a  moment) I mean, I didn't.  Mother did for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) What happened to the singing? You're not in a show, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no!  Nothing like that.  Mother  always thought - she used to talk  about Grand Opera for me.  Imagine! An American girl, for one thing - and then my voice isn't really  that kind anyway, it's just that  Mother - you know what mothers are  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden look comes over Kane's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I do sing a  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to the piano) Would you sing for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bashful) Oh, you wouldn't want to hear me  sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would.  That's why I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me your toothache is  bothering you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, that's all gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have no alibi at all. Please sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, with a tiny ladylike hesitancy, goes to the piano sings a polite song.  Sweetly, nicely, she sings with a s untrained voice.  Kane listens.  He is relaxed, at ease w the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan tosses down a drink, then goes on with her story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did a lot of singing after that. I sang for Charlie -  I sang for  teachers at a hundred bucks an  hour - the teachers got that, I didn't -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glares at him  balefully) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get a thing.  Just the  music lessons.  That's all there  was to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He married you, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in love with me.  But he  never told me so until after it  all came out in the papers about  us - and he lost the election and that Norton woman divorced him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted me to be comfortable - Oh, why should I bother?  You don't  believe me, but it's true.  It  just happens to be true.  He was  really interested in my voice. (sharply) What are you smiling for?  What do  you think he built that opera house  for?  I didn't want it.  I didn't want to sing.  It was his idea - everything was his idea - except  my leaving him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is singing.  Matisti, her voice teacher, is playing piano.  Kane is seated nearby.  Matisti stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible!  Impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your job isn't to give Mrs. Kane  your opinion of her talents. You're supposed to train her voice. Nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating) But, it is impossible.  I will be  the laughingstock of the musical world!  People will say -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're interested in what people  say, Signor Matisti, I may be able  to enlighten you a bit.  The  newspapers, for instance.  I'm an  authority on what the papers will  say, Signor Matisti, because I own  eight of them between here and San  Francisco...  It's all right, dear. Signor Matisti is going to listen  to reason.  Aren't you, maestro? (he looks him square  in the eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kane, how can I persuade you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence.  Matisti rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd see it my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the same opening night - it is the same moment as b except taht the camera is now upstage angling toward the  audience.  The curtain is down.  We see the same tableau before - the terrified and trembling Susan, the apprehens principals, the maids and singing teachers, the stage han As the dissolve commences, there is the sound of applause (exactly as before) and now as the dissolve completes its the orchestra breaks frighteningly into opening chords of music - the stage is cleared - Susan is left alone, terri alone.  The curtain rises.  The glare of the footlights j into the image.  The curtain is now out of the picture an Susan starts to sing.  Beyond her, we see the prompter's containing the anxious face of the prompter.  Beyond that in the darkness - an apprehensive conductor struggles wit task of coordinating an orchestra and an incompetent sing Beyond that - dimly white shirt fronts and glistening bos for a couple of rows, and then deep and terrible darkness Closeup of Kane's face - seated in the audience - listeni Sudden but perfectly correct lull in the music reveals a from the audience - a few words from a sentence - the kin thing that often happens in a theatre -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - really pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music crashes in and drowns out the rest of the sentence, hundreds of people around the voice have heard it (as wel Kane) and there are titters which grow in volume. Closeup of Susan's face - singing. Closeup of Kane's face - listening. There is the ghastly sound of three thousand people appla as little as possible.  Kane still looks.  Then, near the camera, there is the sound of about a dozen people applau very, very loudly.  Camera moves back, revealing Bernstei Reilly and other Kane stooges, seated around him, beating palms together.  The curtain is falling - as we can see b light which shutters down off their faces. The stage from Kane's angle. The curtain is down - the lights glowing on it.  Still, t polite applause dying fast.  Nobody comes out for a bow. Closeup of Kane - breathing heavily.  Suddenly he starts applaud furiously. The stage from the audience again. Susan appears for her bow.  She can hardly walk.  There i little polite crescendo of applause, but it is sickly. Closeup of Kane - still applauding very, very hard, his e on Susan. The stage again. Susan, finishing her bow, goes out through the curtains. light on the curtain goes out and the houselights go on. Closeup of Kane - still applauding very, very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some weeks later.  Susan, in a negligee, is at the window There are the remains of her breakfast tray on a little t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't propose to have yourself  made ridiculous?  What about me? I'm the one that has to do the  singing.  I'm the one that gets  the razzberries. (pauses) Last week, when I was shopping,  one of the salesgirls did an  imitation of me for another girl.   She thought I didn't see her, but -   Charlie, you might as well make up  your mind to it.  This is one thing  you're not going to have your own  way about.  I can't sing and you  know it -  Why can't you just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane rises and walks toward her.  There is cold menace in walk.  Susan shrinks a little as he draws closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My reasons satisfy me, Susan.  You  seem unable to understand them.  I  will not tell them to you again. (he is very close  to her) You will continue with your singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are relentlessly upon her.  She sees something i them that frightens her.  She nods her head slowly, indic surrender.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: Front page of the "San Francisco Enquirer" containing a l portrait of Susan as Thais (as before).  It is announced Susan will open an independent season in San Francisco in "Thais."  The picture remains constant but the names of t papers change from New York to St. Louis, to Los Angeles Cleveland, to Denver to Philadelphia - all "Enquirers." During all this, on the soundtrack, Susan's voice is hear singing her aria very faintly and far away, her voice cra a little. At the conclusion of this above, Susan has finished her s and there is the same mild applause as before - over the of this, one man loudly applauding.  This fades out as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera angles across the bed and Susan's form towards door, from the other side of which voices can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have your keys, Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key must be in the other side. (pause) We'll knock the door down, Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Mrs. Kane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door crashes open, light floods in the room, revealin Susan, fully dressed, stretched out on the bed, one arm d over the side.  Kane rushes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Dr. Corey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes out.  Susan is breathing, but heavily.  Kane lo the lace collar at her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later.  All the lights are lit.  Susan, in a nig is in bed, asleep.  Raymond and a nurse are just leaving room, Raymond closing the door quietly behind him.  Dr. C rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be perfectly all right in a  day or two, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane nods.  He has a small bottle in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse has complete instructions,  but if you care to talk to me at  any time, I should be only too  glad -  I shall be here in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  I can't imagine how  Mrs. Kane came to make such a silly  mistake.  The sedative Dr. Wagner  gave her is in a somewhat larger  bottle -  I suppose the strain of  preparing for her trip has excited  and confused her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that's it. (he starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no objections to my  staying here with her, are there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  I'd like the nurse to  be here, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Corey leaves.  Kane settles himself in a chair next t bed, looking at Susan.  In a moment, the nurse enters, go a chair in the corner of the room, and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, utterly spent, is lying flat on her back in her be Kane is in the chair beside her.  The nurse is out of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a voice that  comes from far  away) I couldn't make you see how I felt,  Charlie.  I just couldn't -  I  couldn't go threw with singing  again.  You don't know what it  means to feel - to know that people -  that an audience don't want you.   That if you haven't got what they  want - a real voice - they just don't care about you.   Even when they're polite - and  they don't laugh or get restless  or - you know...  They don't want  you.  They just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) That's when you've got to fight  them.  That's when you've got to  make them.  That's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan's head turns and she looks at him silently with pat eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (he leans over to  pat her hand) You won't have to fight them  anymore. (he smiles a little) It's their loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gratefully, Susan, with difficulty, brings her other hand to cover his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closeup of an enormous jigsaw puzzle.  A hand is putting the last piece.  Camera moves back to reveal jigsaw puzzl spread out on the floor. Susan is on the floor before her jigsaw puzzle.  Kane is easy chair.  Behind them towers the massive Renaissance  fireplace.  It is night and Baroque candelabra illuminate scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!  I said, what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up - consults  his watch) Half past eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half past eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  The bulldog's just gone to  press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Hurray for the bulldog! (sighs) Half past eleven!  The shows have  just let out.  People are going to  night clubs and restaurants.  Of  course, we're different.  We live  in a palace - at the end of the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always said you wanted to live  in a palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we go back, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks at her smilingly and turns back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I promise to be a good girl! Not to drink - and to entertain  all the governors and the senators with dignity - (she puts a slur  into the word) Charlie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is still no answer.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE IN
dialogues.text: Another picture puzzle - Susan's hands fitting in a missi piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another picture puzzle - Susan's hands fitting in a missi piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another picture puzzle. Camera pulls back to show Kane and Susan in much the same positions as before, except that they are older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I've never been able to  understand, Susan.  How do you  know you haven't done them before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan shoots him an angry glance.  She isn't amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes a whole lot more sense  than collecting Venuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be right -  I sometimes  wonder - but you get into the habit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) It's not a habit.  I do it because  I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was referring to myself. (pauses) I thought we might have a picnic  tomorrow - it might be a nice change  after the Wild West party tonight.   Invite everybody to go to the  Everglades -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throws down a piece  of the jigsaw puzzle  and rises) Invite everybody!  Order everybody,  you mean, and make them sleep in  tents!  Who wants to sleep in tents  when they have a nice room of their own - with their own bath, where  they know where everything is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane has looked at her steadily, not hostilely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we might invite everybody  to go on a picnic tomorrow.  Stay  at Everglades overnight. (he pats her lightly  on the shoulder) Please see that the arrangements  are made, Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane turns away - to Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember my son, Mr. Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the soundtrack we hear the following lines of dialogue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrased) Oh, yes.  How do you do, Mr. Kane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, camera holds on closeup of Susan's face.  Sh very angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shot - of a number of classy tents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two real beds have been set up on each side of the tent. rather classy dressing table is in the rear, at which Sus preparing for bed.  Kane, in his shirt-sleeves, is in an chair, reading.  Susan is very sullen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to put up with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it. (she catches a slight  flicker on Kane's  face) Oh, I know I always say I mean it,  and then I don't - or you get me  so don't do what I say I'm going  to - but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You're in a tent, darling.  You're  not at home.  And I can hear you  very well if you just talk in a  normal tone of voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to have my guests insulted, just because you think - (in a rage) - if people want to bring a drink  or two along on a picnic, that's their business.  You've got no  right -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I've got more than a right as far  as you're concerned, Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sick and tired of you  telling me what I must and what I  musn't do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) You're my wife, Susan, and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just your wife, I'm a person  all by myself - or I ought to be.   I was once.  Sometimes you get me  to believing I never was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can discuss all this some other time, Susan.  Right now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll discuss what's on my mind  when I want to.  You're not going  to keep on running my life the way  you want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as you're concerned, Susan,  I've never wanted anything -  I  don't want anything now - except  what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want me to want, you mean. What you've decided I ought to  have - what you'd want if you were  me.  But you've never given me  anything that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, I really think -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mean the things you've  given me - that don't mean anything  to you.  What's the difference  between giving me a bracelet or  giving somebody else a hundred  thousand dollars for a statue you're  going to keep crated up and never  look at?  It's only money.  It  doesn't mean anything.  You're not  really giving anything that belongs  to you, that you care about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has risen) Susan, I want you to stop this. And right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going to stop it.   I'm going to say exactly what I  think. (she screams) You've never given me anything.   You've tried to buy me into giving  you something.  You're - (a sudden notion) - it's like you were bribing me!   That's what it's been from the  first moment I met you.  No matter  how much it cost you - your time,  your money - that's what you've  done with everybody you've ever  known.  Tried to bribe them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, with no lessening of her passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking an incredible amount  of nonsense, Susan. (quietly) Whatever I do -  I do - because I  love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love!  You don't love anybody!  Me  or anybody else!  You want to be  loved - that's all you want!  I'm  Charles Foster Kane.  Whatever you  want - just name it and it's yours! Only love me!  Don't expect me to love you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word, Kane slaps her across the face.  They loo each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You - you hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane continues to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never have another chance  to hit me again. (pauses) Never knew till this minute -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, it seems to me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other, fixedly, but she doesn't give wa In fact, the camera on Kane's face shows the beginning of startled look, as of one who sees something unfamiliar an unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is a the window looking out.  He turns as he hears R enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane would like to see you,  Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond waits as Kane hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mrs. Kane - (he can't finish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie has been packing since  morning, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane impetuously walks past him out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed suitcases are on the floor, Susan is completely dr for travelling.  Kane bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Arnold I'm ready, Marie.  He  can get the bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.  Kane closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you realize that everybody  here is going to know about this? That you've packed your bags and ordered the car and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - And left?  Of course they'll hear.  I'm not saying goodbye - except to you - but I never imagined  that people wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane is standing against the door as if physically barrin way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stop me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane keeps looking at her.  Susan reaches out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Don't go, Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not start all over again,  Charlie.  We've said everything  that can be said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, don't go!  Susan, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has lost all pride.  Susan stops.  She is affected by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't go, Susan.   Everything'll be exactly the way  you want it.  Not the way I think  you want it - by your way.  Please,  Susan - Susan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is staring at him.  She might weaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go, Susan!  You mustn't go! (almost blubbering) You - you can't do this to me, Susan -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as if he had thrown ice water into her face.  She fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see - it's you that this is being  done to!  It's not me at all.  Not  how I feel.  Not what it means to  me. (she laughs) I can't do this to you! (she looks at him) Oh, yes I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out, past Kane, who turns to watch her go, like very tired old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Thompson at a table.  There is silence between for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you've never heard of how  I lost all my money - and it was plenty, believe me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last ten years have been tough  on a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't been tough on me.  I  just lost my money.  But when I  compare these last ten years with the twenty I spent with him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel kind of sorry for him, all the same -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Don't you think I do? (pause) You say you're going down to Xanadu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday, with some of the boys from  the office.  Mr. Rawlston wants  the whole place photographed  carefully - all that art stuff.   We run a picture magazine, you  know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  If you're smart, you'll  talk to Raymond.  That's the butler. You can learn a lot from him.  He  knows where the bodies are buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shivers.  The dawn light from the skylight above has brighter, making the artificial light in the night club l particularly ghastly, revealing mercilessly every year of Susan's age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you know?  It's  morning already. (looks at him) You must come around and tell me  the story of your life sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open door shows the pantry, which is dark.  Thompson a Raymond are at a table.  There is a pitcher of beer and a of sandwiches before them.  Raymond drinks a glass of bee settles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir - yes, sir, I knew how to  handle the old man.  He was kind  of queer, but I knew how to handle  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I guess he wasn't very happy  those last years - he didn't have much reason to be -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond walking rapidly along corridor.  He pushes open a At a desk in a fairly elaborate telegraph office sits a w operator named Fred.  Near him at a telephone switchboard a female operator named Katherine (not that it matters).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Mr. Charles Foster Kane announced  today that Mrs. Charles Foster  Kane has left Xanadu, his Florida  home, under the terms of a peaceful  and friendly agreement with the  intention of filing suit for divorce  at an early date.  Mrs. Kane said  that she does not intend to return  to the operatic career which she  gave up a few years after her  marriage, at Mr.  Kane's request.   Signed, Charles Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred finishes typing and then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exclusive for immediate  transmission.  Urgent priority all  Kane papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the buzzer on the switchboard.  Kat puts in a plug and answers the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... yes...  Mrs. Tinsdall - Very well. (turns to Raymond) It's the housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says there's some sort of  disturbance up in Mrs. Alexander's  room.  She's afraid to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The housekeeper, Mrs. Tinsdall, and a couple of maids are the door but are too afraid to be in front of it.  From i can be heard a terrible banging and crashing.  Raymond hu into scene, opens the door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane, in a truly terrible and absolutely silent rage, is  literally breaking up the room - yanking pictures, hooks all off the wall, smashing them to bits - ugly, gaudy pic Susie's pictures in Susie's bad taste.  Off of occasional tables, bureaus, he sweeps Susie's whorish accumulation o bric-a-brac. Raymond stands in the doorway watching him.  Kane says no He continues with tremendous speed and surprising strengt still wordlessly, tearing the room to bits.  The curtains frilly - overly pretty) are pulled off the windows in a s gesture, and from the bookshelves he pulls down double ar of cheap novels - discovers a half-empty bottle of liquor dashes it across the room.  Finally he stops.  Susie's co little chamber is an incredible shambles all around him. He stands for a minute breathing heavily, and his eye lig on a hanging what-not in a corner which had escaped his n Prominent on its center shelf is the little glass ball wi the snowstorm in it.  He yanks it down.  Something made o china breaks, but not the glass ball.  It bounces on the and rolls to his feet, the snow in a flurry.  His eye fol it.  He stoops to pick it up - can't make it.  Raymond pi it up for him; hands it to him.  Kane takes it sheepishly looks at it - moves painfully out of the room into the co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane comes out of the door.  Mrs. Tinsdall has been joine by a fairly sizable turnout of servants.  They move back from Kane, staring at him.  Raymond is in the doorway beh Kane.  Kane looks at the glass ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning) Close the door, Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (he closes it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock it - and keep it locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond locks the door and comes to his side.  There is a pause - servants staring in silence.  Kane gives the glas ball a gentle shake and starts another snowstorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond - (he is almost in a  trance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the younger servants giggles and is hushed up.  Ka shakes the ball again.  Another flurry of snow.  He watch the flakes settle - then looks up.  Finally, taking in th pack of servants and something of the situations, he puts glass ball in his coat pocket.  He speaks very quietly to Raymond, so quietly it only seems he's talking to himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly walks off down the corridor, the servants givin to let him pass, and watching him as he goes.  He is an o old man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dissolve completes itself, camera is travellling a the floor of the chapel past the crypts of Kane's father mother - (marked: James Kane - 18- TO 19-; Mary Kane - 18 19-;) - past a blank crypt, and then holding on the buria Kane's son.  A group of ordinary workmen in ordinary clot are lowering a very expensive-looking coffin into its cry Kane stands nearby with Raymond, looking on.  The men str and grunt as the coffin bangs on the stone floor.  The me place over it a long marble slab on which is cut the word CHARLES FOSTER KANE II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Kane, we won't be able to cement it till tommorrow.  We -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane looks right through him.  Raymond cuts him short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men tip their hats and shuffle out of the chapel.  Ka raises his head, looks at the inscription on the wall.  I a little to one side of Junior's grave, directly over the place which will be occupied by Kane himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like poetry, Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kane liked poetry -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond is now convinced that the old master is very far indeed - not to say off his trolley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my wife - not either of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the grave next to his son's - the grave marke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching on) Oh, yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back up at  the wall) Do you know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more his keeper  than his butler  now) It's a wall you bought in China,  Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persia.  It belonged to a king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get him to part with  it, Mr. Kane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was dead...  That's a poem.  Do  you know what it means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't, Mr. Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't used to be afraid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause.  His eyes still on the wall, but looking t it, Kane quotes the translation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunkeness of youth has passed  like a fever, And yet I saw many  things, Seeing my glory in the  days of my glory, I thought my  power eternal And the days of my  life Fixed surely in the years But  a whisper came to me From Him who  dies not.  I called my tributary  kings together And those who were  proud rulers under me, I opened  the boxes of my treasure to them,  saying: "Take hills of gold,  moutains of silver, And give me  only one more day upon the earth." But they stood silent, Looking  upon the ground; So that I died  And Death came to sit upon my  throne.  O sons of men You see a  stranger upon the road, You call  to him and he does not step.  He  is your life Walking towards time,  Hurrying to meet the kings of India  and China. (quoting) O sons of men You are caught in  the web of the world And the spider  Nothing waits behind it.  Where  are the men with towering hopes? They have changed places with owls,  Owls who have lived in tombs And  now inhabit a palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane still stares at the wall, through it, and way beyond Raymond looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson and Raymond.  Raymond has finished his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (callously) That's the whole works, right up  to date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentimental fellow, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes and no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to his  feet) Well, thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean?  He was a little  gone in the head - the last couple  of years, anyway - but I knew how  to handle him. (rises) That "Rosebud" - that don't mean  anything.  I heard him say it. He just said "Rosebud" and then he  dropped that glass ball and it  broke on the floor.  He didn't say  anything about that, so I knew he  was dead - He said all kind of  things I couldn't make out.  But I  knew how to take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go on asking questions if  you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) We're leaving tonight.  As soon as  they're through photographing the stuff -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson has risen.  Raymond gets to his feet and goes to door, opening it for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow yourself plenty of time.   The train stops at the Junction On  signal - but they don't like to  wait.  Not now.  I can remember  when they'd wait all day ... if  Mr. Kane said so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond ushes Thompson into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magnificent tapestries, candelabra, etc., are still t but now several large packing cases are piled against the some broken open, some shut and a number of objects, grea small, are piled pell mell all over the place.  Furniture statues, paintings, bric-a-brac - things of obviously eno value are standing beside a kitchen stove, an old rocking and other junk, among which is also an old sled, the self story.  Somewhere in the back, one of the vast Gothic win of the hall is open and a light wind blows through the sc rustling the papers. In the center of the hall, a Photographer and his Assista are busy photographing the sundry objects.  The floor is  littered with burnt-out flash bulbs.  They continue their throughout the early part of the scene so that now and th flash bulb goes off.  In addition to the Photographer and Assistant, there are a Girl and Two Newspaperment - the S and Third Men of the projection room scene - also Thompso Raymond. The Girl and the Second Man, who wears a hat, are dancing somewhere in the back of the hall to the music of a phono A flash bulb goes off.  The Photographer has just photogr a picture, obviously of great value, an Italian primitive The Assistant consults a label on the back of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Third Newspaperman starts to jot this information dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nativity" - attributed to  Donatello, acquired Florence 1921,  cost 45,000 lira.  Got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!  Next!  Better get that  statue over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Photographer and his Assitant start to move off with equipment towards a large sculpture in another part of th hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think all that is worth,  Mr. Thompson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millions - if anybody wants it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banks are out of luck, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  They'll clear  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Venus," Fourth Century.  Acquired  1911.  Cost twenty-three thousand. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting the statue  on the fanny) That's a lot of money to pay for a  dame without a head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading a label) No. 483.  One desk from the estate  of Mary Kane, Little Salem,  Colorado.  Value $6.00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight bulb goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all set to get everything.   The junk as well as the art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson has opened a box and is idly playing with a hand of little pieces of cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a jigsaw puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a lot of those.  There's a  Burmese Temple and three Spanish  ceilings down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, all in crates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a part of a Scotch castle  over there, but we haven't bothered  to unwrap it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how they put all those  pieces together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading a label) Iron stove.  Estate of Mary Kane. Value $2.00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it over by that statue.  It'll  make a good setup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Who is she anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venus.  She always is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure liked to collect things,  didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went right on buying - right up  to the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything and everything - he was a  regular crow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wonder -  You put all this together - the palaces and the paintings and  the toys and everything - what  would it spell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson has turned around.  He is facing the camera for first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Foster Kane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another flash bulb goes off.  The Photographer turns to T with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Rosebud?  How about it, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the dancers) Turn that thing off, will you?   It's driving me nuts!  What's  Rosebud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kane's last words, aren't they,  Jerry? (to the Third  Newspaperman) That was Jerry's angle, wasn't it,  Jerry?  Did you ever find out what  it means, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music has stopped.  The dancers have come over to Tho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what did you find out about  him, anyway, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing with a jigsaw puzzle -   I  talked to a lot of people who knew  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - it's become a very clear  picture.  He was the most honest  man who ever lived, with a streak  of crookedness a yard wide.  He  was a liberal and a reactionary;  he was tolerant - "Live and Let  Live" - that was his motto.  But  he had no use for anybody who  disagreed with him on any point,  no matter how small it was.  He  was a loving husband and a good  father - and both his wives left  him and his son got himself killed  about as shabbily as you can do  it.  He had a gift for friendship  such as few men have - he broke  his oldest friend's heart like  you'd throw away a cigarette you were through with.  Outside of  that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Rosebud?  Don't you  think that explains anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.  Not much anway.   Charles Foster Kane was a man who  got everything he wanted, and then  lost it.  Maybe Rosebud was  something he couldn't get or lost.   No, I don't think it explains anything.  I don't think any word  explains a man's life.  No -  I  guess Rosebud is just a piece in a  jigsaw puzzle - a missing piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the jigsaw pieces back into the box, looking at watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better get along.  We'll miss  the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his overcoat - it has been resting on a littl sled - the little sled young Charles Foster Kane hit That with at the opening of the picture.  Camera doesn't close on this.  It just registers the sled as the newspaper peo picking up their clothes and equipment, move out of the g hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large furnace, with an open door, dominates the scene. laborers, with shovels, are shovelling things into the fu Raymond is about ten feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw that junk in, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera travels to the pile that he has indicated.  It is bits of broken packing cases, excelsior, etc.  The sled i top of the pile.  As camera comes close, it shows the fad rosebud and, though the letters are faded, unmistakably t word "ROSEBUD" across it.  The laborer drops his shovel, the sled in his hand and throws it into the furnace.  The start to devour it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No lights are to be seen.  Smoke is coming from a chimney Camera reverses the path it took at the beginning of the  picture, perhaps omitting some of the stages.  It moves f through the gates, which close behind it.  As camera paus for a moment, the letter "K" is prominent in the moonligh Just before we fade out, there comes again into the pictu the pattern of barbed wire and cyclone fencing.  On the f is a sign which reads:
